name: Ileana Ros-Lehtinen
allegation: using campaign funds for personal expenses
text: Former Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen is under federal investigation by the Justice Department for allegedly spending campaign money on [personal trips](https://miami.cbslocal.com/2020/09/25/former-florida-representative-ileana-ros-lehtinen-federal-investigation/) while in her final Congressional term.

name: Steve Watkins
allegation: interfering with law enforcement by providing false information, voting without being qualified and unlawful advance voting
text: In 2020, the district attorney of Shawnee County, KS, charged Rep. Watkins [with three felonies](https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/14/us/steve-watkins-voter-fraud-kansas.html) after he voted in the wrong city council district in a 2019 municipal election and subsequently lied to law enforcement. On July 17, 2020, in accordance with House GOP conference rules, [Rep. Watkins stepped down from his committee positions](https://www.kansascity.com/news/politics-government/article244299452.html). In August 2020, Rep. Watkins [lost in the Kansas primary](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/07/14/kansas-gop-rep-watkins-indicted-for-voter-fraud-362072) and will leave Congress in January 2021. On August 14, the House Ethics Committee [established an Investigative Subcommittee](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-steve).

name: Kelly Loeffler
allegation: trading stock based on learning non-public information in committee meetings
text: At some point between March 2020 when news broke that stocks owned by Sen. Loeffler were sold right after a committee briefing on the possible trajectory of covid19 and June 17, 2020, the Senate Ethics Committee opened an investigation into the trades. On June 17, they [sent a letter](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/senate-ethics-panel-dismisses-probe-into-sen-loeffler-for-insider-trading/2020/06/16/f8ca3196-b01e-11ea-8f56-63f38c990077_story.html) to Sen. Loeffler informing her than since the Department of Justice had ended its investigation, they would too. No record of the investigation or the letter are available publicly.

name: Sanford Bishop
allegation: spending Members’ Representational Allowance (MRA) funds on holiday events in his district and converting campaign funds to personal use
text: In June 2020, the House Committee on Ethics announced it would [continue an investigation](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-11) into Rep. Bishop for unstated reasons based on an unpublished February 2020 referral from the Office of Congressional Ethics. On July 31, the House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics (OCE) Report and Findings](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-14) and the member's response. The OCE reported that the allegations were of spending Members’ Representational Allowance (MRA) funds on holiday events in his district and converting campaign funds to personal use

name: Richard Burr
allegation: covid19 stock profiteering
text: In March 2020, Sen. Burr was accused of covid19 stock profiteering by selling stocks based on information learned in non-public briefings. On March 20, Sen. Burr asked the Senate Select Committee on Ethics to [open an investigation](https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/19/politics/richard-burr-coronavirus-comments/index.html) into his actions. There is no indication that the Committee has acted on his request. On March 30, news reports indicated that the Federal Bureau of Investigations (FBI) and the Securities & Exchange Commission (SEC) [were investigating](https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/politics-government/article241646666.html) Sen. Burr. On May 14, Sen. Burr stepped down as chair of the Senate Intelligence Committee after it was reported that [the FBI had seized his mobile phone](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/05/14/sen-richard-burrs-phone-seized-fbi-serves-warrant-stock-probe/5188726002/).

name: Lori Trahan
allegation: accepting excessive campaign contributions and failing to file required disclosure documents
text: In September 2019, Trahan was accused of accepting excessive campaign contributions and failing to file required disclosure documents. In December 2019, the House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and the member's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-lori-0). In July 2020, the House Committee on Ethics [published its report dismissing the charges](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/documents/Committee%20Report_17.pdf) since the alleged excessive contributions were part of joint holdings with her spouse and any reporting errors were unintentional.

name: Rashida Tlaib
allegation: reporting improper campaign expenditures
text: In 2019, Tlaib was accused of reporting improper campaign expenditures. In August, the Office of Congressional Ethics [recommended further review](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-referral-regarding-rep-rashida-tlaib) by the House Committee on Ethics. In November, the House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and the member's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-17). In August 2020, the House Committee on Ethics found that while Rep. Tlaib did receive campaign funds for personal use after the 2018 general election, it was an error and not malfeasance. She is fined $10,800, the amount she received after the election.

name: Ross Spano
allegation: receiving improper and excessive loans for his election campaign
text: In 2019, Spano was accused of receiving improper and excessive loans for his election campaign. In August, the Office of Congressional Ethics [recommended further review](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-report-regarding-rep-ross-spano) by the House Committee on Ethics. In November, the House Committee on Ethics [deferred its investigation to the Department of Justice](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-ross-0).

name: Bill Huizenga
allegation: accepting campaign contributions from staff and making improper campaign expenditures
text: In 2019, Huizenga was accused of accepting campaign contributions from staff and making improper campaign expenditures. In August, the Office of Congressional Ethics [recommended further review](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-referral-regarding-rep-bill-huizenga) by the House Committee on Ethics. In November, the House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-bill-2).

name: Alcee Hastings
allegation: engaging in improper relationship with a staff member and receiving improper gifts and/or forebearance from the staff member
text: In 2019, Hastings was alleged to have engaged in improper relationship with a staff member and received improper gifts and/or forebearance from the staff member. The House Committee on Ethics began an investigation. In 2020, the House Committee on Ethics [closed the investigation](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-10) since the employee was his spouse, gifts from family are acceptable and their employment did not violate any House rules when they were hired.

name: Michael F. Q. San Nicolas
allegation: engaging in a sexual relationship with a staff member, converting campaign funds to personal use and/or accepting improper or excessive campaign contributions
text: In 2019, San Nicolas was alleged to have engaged in a sexual relationship with a staff member, converted campaign funds to personal use and/or accepted improper or excessive campaign contributions. The House Committee on Ethics began an investigation. In 2020, the House Committee on Ethics[established an Investigative Subcommittee](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-delegate-michael-f-0) to further investigate the allegations following a referral from the Office of Congressional Ethics.

name: Katie Hill
allegation: had a sexual relationship with office staffer
text: In October 2019, nude photos of Rep. Hill were published by conservative websites along with the allegation that she was having a sexual relationship with her Chief of Staff. Rep. Hill claimed that the photos & allegation came from her soon to be ex-husband as part of their divorce. Rep. Hill denied that allegation, which would have been a violation of House rules, but did acknowledge a relationship with a campaign staff member which is not against House rules. A few days after the House Ethics Committee opened an investigation into Rep. Hill, she resigned from Congress.

name: Raúl Grijalva
allegation: the representative created a hostile work environment and was frequently drunk
text: At an unspecified date during Rep. Grijalva's service in Congress, he was accused of creating a hostile work environment and being frequently drunk. The claims, always denied by Grijalva, were resolved with a severance payment in 2015 although none of this became public until 2017. According to news reports, Grijalva was cleared by the House Ethics Committee [letter](https://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/house-ethics-clears-rep-raul-grijalva-wrongdoing) in Dec 2018. Now, his case is apparently [being reviewed by the House Committee on Ethics](https://www.azcentral.com/story/news/politics/arizona/2019/06/14/rep-raul-grijalva-under-scrutiny-house-ethics-committee-over-workplace-allegations/1460308001/), although what for and why is unknown.

name: Matt Gaetz
allegation: violating the Florida Supreme Court's rules for attorney by attempting to intimidate a witness scheduled to testify before the House Judiciary Committee.
text: In February 2019, Gaetz posted a threatening tweet aimed at Michael Cohen, President Trump's former personal attorney the night before Cohen was scheduled to testify before the House Judiciary Committee regarding crimes for which Cohen had been found guilty and in which, according to federal prosecutors, the President participated. Gaetz was [referred to the Florida Bar for investigation](http://www.tampabay.com/florida-politics/buzz/2019/02/27/matt-gaetz-under-investigation-by-the-florida-bar-for-tweet-at-michael-cohen/) and possible discipline. In August 2019, the [Florida Bar announced it had found "no probable cause"](https://www.tampabay.com/florida-politics/buzz/2019/08/14/no-probable-cause-matt-gaetz-violated-florida-bar-rules-in-tweets-at-michael-cohen/) that Gaetz had violated its rules and closed its investigation. Because of his [repeated refusals](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-matt) to respond to House Committee on Ethics requests for interviews, an Investigative Subcommittee was established in June 2019. In August 2020, the House Committee on Ethics published the report of the Investigative Subcommittee [admonishing Gaetz for unprofessional behavior](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/documents/Committee%20Report_21.pdf).

name: Robin Hayes
allegation: bribery and conspiracy to commit honest services wire fraud, along with several counts of making false statements
text: In 2019, Mr. Hayes, the Republican representative for NC-8 from 1999-2008 and current chair of the North Carolina Republican Party, was indicted on charges of bribery and conspiracy to commit honest services wire fraud, along with several counts of making false statements in an effort to bribe North Carolina's insurance commissioner. In October 2019, Mr. Hayes pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI while being investigated for conspiracy and bribery.

name: Rod Blum
allegation: omitting required information from financial disclosure reports; permitting the use of official House resources for a private business in which he had a financial interest and the use of unfair or deceptive trade practices
text: In 2018, Blum was accused of omitting required information from financial disclosure reports; permitting the use of official House resources for a private business in which he had a financial interest and the use of unfair or deceptive trade practices. In July 2018, the Office of Congressional Ethics [referred the allegations to the House Committee on Ethics for further investigation](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-referral-regarding-rep-rod-blum). In December 2018, the House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and the member's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-ro-0). In January 2019, the Committee ceased investigating as its juridiction ended with the 115th Congress.

name: Thomas Garrett
allegation: using Congressional staff to perform unofficial work and personal errands
text: In May 2018, Garrett [announced he is an alcoholic](https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/rep-garrett-announces-he-is-an-alcoholic-and-will-not-seek-re-election/2018/05/28/40e8839a-62b2-11e8-99d2-0d678ec08c2f_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.83dc5ec2e388) and that he would not run for re-election at the same time that allegations that he had been using Congressional staff to perform unofficial work and personal errands emerged. In September 2018, the Office of Congressional Ethics [referred the allegations](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-referral-regarding-rep-thomas-garrett) to the House Committee on Ethics. In December 2018, the House Committee on Ethics announced it was [extending its investigation](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-26) The investigation ceased with the end of the 115th Congress as Garrett is no longer in Congress.

name: James Renacci
allegation: misusing his congressional office for campaign purposes
text: In April 2018, the Ohio Democratic Party [filed a complaint against Renacci with the Office of Congressional Ethics](https://www.dispatch.com/news/20180430/ohio-democrats-file-ethics-complaint-against-renacci) for misusing his congressional office for campaign purposes. In November 2018, Renacci lost the Senate election to Sherrod Brown and the House Committee on Ethics [extended its investigation of the allegations](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-jim). The Committee ceased investigating at the end of the 115th because they no longer had jurisdiction.

name: Pramila Jayapal
allegation: crowding, obstructing, or incommoding, during a protest inside a Senate Office Building in Washington, D.C.
text: On June 28, Rep. Jayapal was arrested for crowding, obstructing, or incommoding, during a protest inside a Senate Office Building in Washington, D.C. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that [no further investigation was needed](https://www.congress.gov/115/crpt/hrpt876/CRPT-115hrpt876.pdf) since Rep. Jayapal had paid a $50 fine and charges were dropped.

name: David Schweikert
allegation: using or authorizing impermissable expenditures from Representative Schweikert’s Members’ Representational Allowance and receiving improper campaign contributions; failure to provide financial disclosure information
text: In 2018, Rep. Schweikert was accused of using or authorizing impermissable expenditures from his Members’ Representational Allowance and receiving improper campaign contributions. In June 2018, the House Committee on Ethics [established an Investigative Subcommittee (ISC)](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-19). In December of 2018, the ISC [expanded its investigation](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-28) and added alleged failure to make financial disclosures. On July 30, 2020, the House Committee on Ethics published their report, [concluded he was guilty of all charges](https://ethics.house.gov/press-releases/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-13), recommended a reprimand and fined Schweikert $50,000. On July 31, 2020, the [House voted unanimously](https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/house-votes-to-reprimand-gop-rep-schweikert-for-11-ethics-violations/2020/07/31/2490303e-d327-11ea-9038-af089b63ac21_story.html) in a voice vote to formally reprimand Rep. Schweikert.

name: Paul Gosar
allegation: attempting to pressure Capitol Police via Twitter to arrest State of the Union 2018 guests he described as "illegal aliens"
text: In February 2018, a resolution to reprimand Rep. Gosar for attempting to pressure Capitol Police via Twitter to arrest State of the Union 2018 guests he described as "illegal aliens" [was tabled (i.e. failed) on party lines, 231-187](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/115-2018/h53). Several Democratic representatives brought undocumented immigrants who are currently part of the DACA program to the speech.

name: Elizabeth Esty
allegation: failed to address sexual harassment by one staffer against another in a timely manner
text: In April of 2018, Rep. Esty announced she would not seek reelection after she admitted that she had [failed to address sexual harassment](https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/02/us/politics/elizabeth-esty-wont-run-reelection.html) by one staffer against another in a timely manner. She said she had also asked for a review of her office's actions by the House Committee on Ethics. In December of 2018, the House Committee on Ethics [found that Esty had broken no House rules](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Esty%20Report%20FINAL%20with%20Signatures.pdf) but that she could have handled the situation better.

name: Devin Nunes
allegation: receiving campaign contributions in excess of limits and from prohibited entities
text: In 2018, the [Federal Elections Commission (FEC) announced it was investigating Nunes](http://docquery.fec.gov/pdf/285/201803200300001285/201803200300001285.pdf) for receiving campaign contributions in excess of limits and from prohibited entities.

name: Brady
allegation: leading a criminal conspiracy to hide a $90,000 payment made to persuade a 2012 primary opponent to drop out of the race
text: Brady faced an allegation of leading a criminal conspiracy to hide a $90,000 payment made to persuade a 2012 primary opponent to drop out of the race. On Nov. 1, 2017, the Federal Bureau of Investigation [issued a search warrant for email](http://www.philly.com/philly/news/pennsylvania/philadelphia/bob-brady-search-warrant-emails-campaign-payoff-probe-20171121.html).

name: Meehan
allegation: sexual harassment
text: While serving on the House Committee on Ethics, Meehan used taxpayer funds to settle a 2017 sexual harassment complaint privately, heading off an investigation. He was subsequently removed from the House Committee on Ethics. In March 2018, the House Committee on Ethics had established and [staffed an Investigative Subcommittee](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-14) When Meehan resigned in April 2018, the Committee ceased investigating because he was no longer within their jurisdiction.

name: John J. Duncan, Jr.
allegation: converting campaign funds to personal use and accepting contributions from staff while reimbursing them for those contributions from the campaign committee
text: In 2017, the Office of Congressional Ethics recommended further review of allegations against Rep. Duncan, Jr. for converting campaign funds to personal use and accepting contributions from staff while reimbursing them for those contributions from the campaign committee. In 2018, the House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and the member's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-jo-3). In January 2019, the Committee ceased investigating as its jurisdiction ended with the 115th Congress.

name: Ruben Kihuen
allegation: sexual harassment
text: On Dec. 15, 2017, the House Committee on Ethics announced that it had begun an investigation into allegations of sexual harassment by Kihuen. On November 16, 2018, the Committee the Committee found that Representative Kihuen made persistent and unwanted advances towards women who were required to interact with him as part of their professional responsibilities. As a result, the Committee voted to adopt the Investigative Subcommittee's report, which along with the Committee's report [will serve as a reproval](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Kihuen%20Com%20Report%20with%20Sigs.pdf) of Kihuen.

name: Luis V. Gutiérrez
allegation: arrest during a protest outside of the White House
text: In 2017 Gutiérrez was investigated for having been arrested during a December protest outside of the White House. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended no action as the fine has been paid](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/DREAMER%20Protest%20Report_0.pdf). On November 28, 2017, Representative Gutiérrez announced he would not seek reelection to Congress.

name: Judy Chu
allegation: arrest during a protest outside of the White House
text: In 2017 Chu was investigated for having been arrested during a December protest outside of the White House. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended no action as the fine has been paid](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/DREAMER%20Protest%20Report_0.pdf).

name: Trent Franks
allegation: asking staff members to carry his surrogate child and offering one staffer $5 million dollars to impregnate her via intercourse
text: In 2017, Franks resigned due to reports that he had asked staff members to carry his surrogate child and had offered one staffer $5 million dollars to impregnate her via intercourse.

name: Al Franken
allegation: sexual harassment
text: On December 7, 2017, Senator Franken announced his resignation which was effective January 2, 2018 due to allegations of sexual harassment. Select Committee on Ethics [began investigating Senator Franken](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/files/serve?File_id=A7DC53D9-3BB6-4C9C-81A9-EA983132193E) on November 30, 2017.

name: John Conyers, Jr.
allegation: sexual harassment, age discrimination, and improper use of official resources for personal purposes
text: On December 5, 2017, Conyers resigned from office at the start of an investigation for sexual harassment, age discrimination, and improper use of official resources for personal purposes.

name: Filner
allegation: groping, sexually suggestive comments, and unwanted advances
text: In 2013 Filner pleaded guilty to groping, sexually suggestive comments and unwanted advances as mayor of San Diego, CA. In Nov. 2017, Rep. Diana DeGettee alleged that Filner had groped her when their Congressional terms overlapped.

name: Robert Menendez
allegation: corruption and bribery
text: Menendez was investigated for unspecified misconduct in 2012. The Senate investigation was halted during his investigation and trial for corruption and bribery which resulted in a mistrial. In April 2018, the Senate Select Committee on Ethics [admonished Senator Menendez](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/files/serve?File_id=49C12C75-7A26-4FE6-B070-19FCEF4D7532) for violating Senate rules and ordered him to repay any remaining outstanding value of impermissable gifts.

name: Weiner
allegation: sending sexually explicit texts to women who were not his wife
text: Weiner sent sexually explicit texts to women who were not his wife, including to a 15-year-old girl. On Jun. 21, 2011, he [resigned](http://content.usatoday.com/communities/onpolitics/post/2011/06/anthony-weiner-resignation-sex-scandal-/1#.WmekVpM-f1I). On Oct. 28, 2016, the Director of the FBI, James Comey, publicly reopened his investigation into presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton because the computer seized as part of the Weiner investigation contained some emails that might have been relevant to a [prior investigation into Clinton](https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/29/us/politics/fbi-hillary-clinton-email.html).

name: William Jefferson
allegation: bribery
text: In 2009 Jefferson was convicted of bribery. In 2012, he was sentenced to 13 years in prison. In 2017, 7 of the 10 indictments were dismissed and he was released from prison.

name: Chris Collins
allegation: sharing material nonpublic information in the purchase of Innate stock, using his status to purchase discounted stock and directing an NIH employee to meet with Innate staff to discuss a clinical trial
text: On Aug. 8, 2018, Collins was [arrested and indicted on charges of insider trading of Innate stock](https://www.businessinsider.com/chris-collins-arrested-insider-trading-charges-2018-8) by the FBI. He had been under investigation by the House Office of Congressional Ethics since 2017 for sharing material nonpublic information in the purchase of Innate stock, using his status to purchase discounted stock, and in 2013 directing an NIH employee to meet with Innate staff to discuss a clinical trial. He briefly suspended his reelection campaign, then unsuspended it and kept his seat. In May 2019, the House Committee on Ethics [reauthorized](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-chris) deferred further investigation to the Department of Justice. On Sept. 30, 2019, Collins [resigned](https://www.foxnews.com/politics/new-yorks-collins-to-resign-house-seat-ahead-of-expected-guilty-plea-for-insider-trading) from Congress and on Oct. 1, 2019, he [pleaded guilty](https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/01/nyregion/chris-collins-guilty-congress.html) to conspiracy to commit securities fraud and lying to federal investigators.

name: Luis V. Gutiérrez
allegation: arrest during a protest outside of the White House
text: In 2017 Gutiérrez was investigated for having been arrested during a protest outside of the White House. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended no action as the fine has been paid](https://www.congress.gov/115/crpt/hrpt310/CRPT-115hrpt310.pdf). On November 28, 2017, Representative Gutiérrez announced he would not seek reelection to Congress.

name: Madeleine Z. Bordallo
allegation: receiving profit from a foreign government; excess gifts; use of official funds for personal travel; using congressional staff for personal services
text: In 2017 Bardallo was investigated for receiving profit from a foreign government; excess gifts; use of official funds for personal travel; and using congressional staff for personal services. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended further review](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-delegate-madelein-0).

name: John Conyers, Jr.
allegation: compensating staff for work in 2016 not commensurate with pay with House of Representatives funds
text: In 2017 Conyers was investigated for compensating staff for work in 2016 not commensurate with pay with House of Representatives funds. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended further review](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-jo-0).

name: Ben Ray Luján
allegation: requesting that his congressional campaign committee issue communications, including requests for donations, using images of him in a “sit-in” demonstration in the House
text: In 2017 Lujan was investigated for requesting that his congressional campaign committee issue communications, including requests for donations, using images of him in a “sit-in” demonstration in the House. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded that no action was needed](https://www.congress.gov/115/crpt/hrpt272/CRPT-115hrpt272.pdf).

name: Roger Williams
allegation: improperly taking official action in 2015 on a matter in which he had a personal financial interest
text: In 2017 Williams was investigated for improperly taking official action in 2015 on a matter in which he had a personal financial interest. The House Committee on Ethics concluded the Williams Amendment could have affected Representative Williams’ personal financial interests, however the totality of the circumstances surrounding Representative Williams’ [actions did not create a reasonable inference of improper conduct](https://www.congress.gov/115/crpt/hrpt271/CRPT-115hrpt271.pdf).

name: Greg Gianforte
allegation: assaulting a reporter in 2017 the night before he was elected to Congress
text: In 2017 Gianforte pleaded guilty to assaulting a reporter in 2017 the night before he was elected to Congress.

name: Devin Nunes
allegation: unauthorized disclosures of classified information
text: In 2017 Nunes was investigated for unauthorized disclosures of classified information. The [investigation is closed](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-6) as of 12/07/2017.

name: Duncan Hunter
allegation: converting funds from his congressional campaign committee for personal use
text: In 2016 Hunter was investigated for converting funds from his congressional campaign committee for personal use. The House Committee on Ethics [deferred to the Department of Justice](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative). In August 2018, Hunter was [indicted](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/congressman-duncan-hunter-wife-charged-with-spending-campaign-money-on-personal-expenses/2018/08/21/). In June 2019, Hunter's wife [pleaded guilty](https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/juliareinstein/duncan-margaret-hunter-california-congressman-guilty-plea) and said that she and Hunter misused over $200,000 in campaign funds for personal purposes. In December 2019, Hunter pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring to misuse campaign funds. The House Committee on Ethics [released the findings of the Office of Congressional Ethics](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-dunc-2) and resumed its investigation. Hunter has yet to announce whether he will resign from Congress.

name: Dennis “Denny” Hastert
allegation: child molestation
text: In 2016 Hastert pleaded guilty to child molestation, 10 years after leaving Congress. In 2006, Hastert declined to run for office again. He was indicted in 2015, served 13 months in prison and was released in 2017.

name: Marlin A. Stutzman
allegation: using campaign funds for a 2015 family trip which included some campaign activity
text: In 2016 Stutzman was investigated for using campaign funds for a 2015 family trip which included some campaign activity. The House Committee on Ethics recommended further review; however after Stutzman's loss in the 2016 election, [the investigation was ended](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt910/CRPT-114hrpt910.pdf).

name: Alan Grayson
allegation: numerous alleged violations, the majority of which relate to his leadership and ownership of a hedge fund and law firms, omissions from his annual financial disclosure forms, and the use of official resources for unofficial purposes
text: In 2015 Grayson was investigated for numerous alleged violations, the majority of which relate to his leadership and ownership of a hedge fund and law firms, omissions from his annual financial disclosure forms, and the use of official resources for unofficial purposes. He lost the 2016 election.

name: Michael M. Honda
allegation: using official resources for campaign purposes
text: In 2015 Honda was investigated for using official resources for campaign purposes. The House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and Rep. Honda's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-14). Honda lost his 2016 election.

name: Corrine Brown
allegation: a range of mail violations, wire fraud, defrauding the IRS and related charges
text: In 2016 Brown was convicted for a range of mail violations, wire fraud, defrauding the IRS and related charges. In 2016, Brown lost in the primary and in 2017 she was [convicted of the charges against her](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corrine_Brown#Political_controversies). In December 2017, she was sentenced to five years in prison.

name: David B. McKinley
allegation: remaining a named partner in his prior business after being elected to Congress
text: In 2016 McKinley received a letter of reproval for remaining a named partner in his prior business after being elected to Congress. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that McKinley violated House rules and [issued a letter of reproval](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt795/CRPT-114hrpt795.pdf).

name: Mark Meadows
allegation: retaining an employee through 2015 who did not perform duties after 2014 commensurate with the compensation the employee received
text: In 2016 Meadows was investigated for retaining an employee through 2015 who did not perform duties after 2014 commensurate with the compensation the employee received. This employee, Mr. West, had been demoted after Meadows learned of West's sexual harassment of other Meadows' staff. Meadows commissioned his own investigation and ignored the recommendation to fire West. Further, Meadows did not seek guidance on whether continuing to pay West was in accordance with House Rules and his separatist approach to keeping West on staff, but away from women staff was effectively discriminatory since it precluded their access to to Meadows. For these reasons, the Committee [unanimously voted to reprove Meadows and to require him to repay West's excess two month's salary of $40,625.02](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Meadows%20Report%20FINAL%20with%20sigs.pdf).

name: Ed Whitfield
allegation: permitting his spouse to lobby him and/or his congressional staff from 2011 to 2014
text: In 2016 Whitfield received a letter of reproval for permitting his spouse to lobby him and/or his congressional staff from 2011 to 2014. The House Committee on Ethics found the violation occured and that [the report would be the reproval](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt687/CRPT-114hrpt687.pdf).

name: Vern Buchanan
allegation: improperly influencing a witness before the FEC and illegally reimbursing campaign contributors
text: In 2012 Buchanan was investigated for improperly influencing a witness before the FEC and illegally reimbursing campaign contributors. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that there was insufficient evidence on the allegation of witness tampering, but that [the illegal reimbursements did occur, albeit without the representative's knowledge](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt643/CRPT-114hrpt643.pdf).

name: Chaka Fattah
allegation: conspiracy, racketeering, bribery, fraud, falsification of records, making false statements, and money laundering after a 2015 House investigation had been launched
text: In 2016 Fattah was convicted for conspiracy, racketeering, bribery, fraud, falsification of records, making false statements, and money laundering after a 2015 House investigation had been launched. The House Committee on Ethics [ended its investigation when Fattah resigned](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt910/CRPT-114hrpt910.pdf). Fattah resigned in 2016, two days after being convicted of the charges. He is currently serving a ten year sentence.

name: Jared Polis
allegation: endorsement of commercial products
text: In 2015 Polis was investigated for official endorsement of commercial products. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded that no action was needed](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt381/CRPT-114hrpt381.pdf).

name: Robert Pittenger
allegation: compensation for his involvement with a fiduciary business, a real estate investment firm known as Pittenger Land Investments, Inc.
text: In 2015 Pittenger was investigated for compensation for his involvement with a fiduciary business, a real estate investment firm known as Pittenger Land Investments, Inc. The House Committee on Ethics [deferred to the Department of Justice](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-robe-2). In May 2017, the [FBI closed the investigation](http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/business/article148497229.html) without making any charges. The Committee ceased investigating with the end of the 115th Congress because Pittenger lost his election and they no longer had jurisdiction.

name: Blake Farenthold
allegation: sexual harassment on the basis of a 2014 lawsuit filed against him alleging sexual harassment
text: In 2015 Farenthold was investigated for sexual harassment on the basis of a 2014 lawsuit filed against him alleging sexual harassment. The [lawsuit was resolved in 2015](http://www.rollcall.com/news/home/farenthold-sexual-harassment-case-settled-court) with a [taxpayer-funded settlement](https://www.politico.com/story/2017/12/01/blake-farenthold-taxpayer-funds-sexual-harassment-274458) that was revealed in 2017, and the House Committee on Ethics investigation was re-opened. On April 6, 2018, Farenthold resigned. On April 12, the House Committee on Ethics [closed the investigation due to loss of jurisdiction](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-17).

name: Michelle Lujan Grisham
allegation: travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel
text: In 2015 Grisham was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

name: Gregory W. Meeks
allegation: travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel
text: In 2015 Meeks was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

name: Ted Poe
allegation: travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel
text: In 2015 Poe was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

name: Jim Bridenstine
allegation: travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel
text: In 2015 Bridenstine was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

name: Yvette D. Clarke
allegation: travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel
text: In 2015 Clarke was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

name: Danny K. Davis
allegation: travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel
text: In 2015 Davis was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

name: Sheila Jackson Lee
allegation: travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel
text: In 2015 Lee was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

name: Leonard Lance
allegation: travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel
text: In 2015 Lance was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf).

name: Rubén Hinojosa
allegation: travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel
text: In 2015 Hinojosa was investigated for travel funded or organized by one or more entities prohibited from providing congressional travel. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded implicated House members did not intentionally accept gifts from prohibited entities](https://www.congress.gov/114/crpt/hrpt239/CRPT-114hrpt239.pdf). Hinojosa did not seek reelection in 2016.

name: Aaron Schock
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions in excess of legally allowed amounts
text: In 2018 Schock will be tried for soliciting campaign contributions in excess of legally allowed amounts. In 2013, the House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and Rep. Schock's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-aaro-0). In 2015, Schock resigned [amid a host of allegations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aaron_Schock#Use_of_funds_scandal) of improper use of campaign funds.

name: Paul C. Broun
allegation: using official resources for campaign purposes
text: In 2014 Broun was investigated for using official resources for campaign purposes. The House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and the member's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-paul-0). Broun lost his 2014 election.

name: Michele Bachmann
allegation: campaign finance violations
text: In 2013 Bachmann was investigated for campaign finance violations. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended further review](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-6). When Bachmann did not seek reelection in 2014, the investigation ende.

name: Timothy H. Bishop
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for constituent services in 2012
text: In 2013 Bishop was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for constituent services in 2012. The House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and the member's response.](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-tim-1). Representative Bishop lost the 2014 election.

name: Thomas E. Petri
allegation: performing official work on behalf of companies in which he had a financial interest from 2008 to 2013
text: In 2014 Petri was investigated for performing official work on behalf of companies in which he had a financial interest from 2008 to 2013. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended no further action](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt666/CRPT-113hrpt666.pdf). Petri announced in November 2014 he would not seek reelection.

name: Alcee L. Hastings
allegation: sexual harassment and employment retaliation
text: In 2012 Hastings was investigated for sexual harassment and employment retaliation. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded that there was insufficient evidence to act further even though the representative admitted to "less than professional behavior"](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt663/CRPT-113hrpt663-pt1.pdf).

name: Phil Gingrey
allegation: compensation from banks on whose behalf he advocated
text: In 2012 Gingrey was investigated for 2011 compensation from banks on whose behalf he advocated. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that Gingrey did advocate for banks in which he had a financial interest and [issued a letter of reproval](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt664/CRPT-113hrpt664.pdf). In 2014, Representative Gingrey lost in the primary for one of Georgia's Senate seats.

name: Judy Chu
allegation: using House staff to perform campaign activities and then obstructing the investigation
text: In 2014 Chu received a letter of reproval for using House staff to perform campaign activities and then obstructing the investigation. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that the campaign work occured without her knowledge but because Chu attempted to obstruct the investigation, [a letter of reproval was issued](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt665/CRPT-113hrpt665.pdf).

name: Michael G. Grimm
allegation: violating federal campaign finance laws by soliciting and accepting prohibited campaign contributions, causing false information to be included in campaign finance reports, and improperly seeking assistance from a foreign national in soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for offering to use his official position to assist that individual in obtaining a green card. This plea came 3 years after the Office of Congressional Ethics began an investigation of the same allegations
text: In 2014 Grimm pleaded guilty to tax evasion after having been investigated for violating federal campaign finance laws by soliciting and accepting prohibited campaign contributions, causing false information to be included in campaign finance reports, and improperly seeking assistance from a foreign national in soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for offering to use his official position to assist that individual in obtaining a green card. This plea came three years after the Office of Congressional Ethics began an investigation of the allegations. Grimm resigned in January 2015 and served seven months in prison.

name: Bobby L. Rush
allegation: allowing state and federal campaign committees to accept in-kind contributions
text: In 2014 Rush was investigated for allowing state and federal campaign committees to accept in-kind contributions. With publication of its report, the [House Committee on Ethics reproved Rush](https://www.congress.gov/115/crpt/hrpt618/CRPT-115hrpt618.pdf) for accepting a gift of rent-free office space even if it did not amount to a campaign contribution and ordered him to repay the value of the gift.

name: Gwen Moore
allegation: an arrest at a 2014 protest in Wisconsin
text: In 2014 Moore was investigated for an arrest at a 2014 protest in Wisconsin. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that the fines would be paid and [no further investigation was required](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt585/CRPT-113hrpt585.pdf).

name: Don Young
allegation: improper travel gifts and failure to disclose them
text: In 2014 Young received a letter of reproval for improper travel gifts and failure to disclose them. The House Committee on Ethics concluded Young had improperly accepted travel gifts and [issued a letter of reproval](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt487/CRPT-113hrpt487.pdf).

name: Steve Stockman
allegation: conspiring to accept contributions to his congressional campaign committee from individuals who were employed by his congressional office
text: Stockman was [convicted of fraud](https://www.texastribune.org/2018/04/12/texas-congressman-steve-stockman-found-guilty-felony-charges/) in 2018 related to personal and other improper use of campaign funds. In 2014 the House began an [investigation](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-stev-0) into conspiring to accept contributions to his congressional campaign committee from individuals who were employed by his congressional office. Stockman lost the 2014 Senate primary and did not win re-election to his House seat.

name: Luis V. Gutiérrez
allegation: using funds from his Members Representational Allowance from 2003-2013 for an impermissible purpose - to retain an individual to provide services to his congressional office that more closely resemble those provided by an employee or consultant, rather than a contractor
text: In 2013 Gutiérrez was investigated for using funds from his Members Representational Allowance from 2003-2013 for an impermissible purpose - to retain an individual to provide services to his congressional office that more closely resemble those provided by an employee or consultant, rather than a contractor. In March 2018, the House Committee on Ethics [reproved Gutiérrez for using his Member Representational Allowance inappropriately, albeit possibly unwittingly,](https://www.congress.gov/115/crpt/hrpt617/CRPT-115hrpt617.pdf) and ordered him to reimburse the US Treasury for that use. On November 28, 2017, Representative Gutiérrez announced he would not seek reelection.

name: Cathy McMorris Rodgers
allegation: using official resources, including staff, for campaign activities; paying a consultant for official services with funds from political committees; combining official resources and campaign resources in furtherance of a campaign for a House leadership office from 2010 to 2012
text: In 2013 Rodgers was investigated for using official resources, including staff, for campaign activities, paying a consultant for official services with funds from political committees, and combining official resources and campaign resources in furtherance of a campaign for a House leadership office from 2010 to 2012. As of 2019, the House Committee on Ethics [has yet to conclude its review](https://www.congress.gov/115/crpt/hrpt1125/CRPT-115hrpt1125.pdf). In December 2019, the Committee completed its review. It ordered Rodgers to [reimburse the House $7575.95 and reproved her for her sloppiness in managing her funds](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-cath-1).

name: Markwayne Mullin
allegation: receiving excess outside earned income, endorsing companies or products as part of outside employment and serving as a board member or officer for outside companies
text: In 2013 Mullin was investigated for receiving excess outside earned income, endorsing companies or products as part of outside employment and serving as a board member or officer of outside companies --- his family's businesses. Because Mullin was already consulting with the House Committee on Ethics about how to handle his relationship with his family's businesses when the Office of Congressional Ethics began its investigation, the House Committee on Ethics concluded that Mullin had been making a good faith effort to be compliant with House rules and [that apart from rectifying a $40,000 accounting error, no further action was warranted](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairwoman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-21).

name: Robert E. Andrews
allegation: improper use of campaign funds for personal use
text: In 2013 Andrews was investigated for improper use of campaign funds for personal use. The House Committee on Ethics [established an independent subcommittee](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative-robe-1). In 2014, Andrews resigned from Congress and House Committee on Ethics' jurisdiction over the member ended.

name: Trey Radel
allegation: possession of cocaine
text: In 2013 Radel pleaded guilty to possession of cocaine. The House Committee on Ethics [ended the investigation when Radel resigned](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt727/CRPT-113hrpt727.pdf). In 2014, [Radel was sentenced to probation, which he served](http://www.news-press.com/story/news/2014/10/30/ex-congressman-trey-radels-record-cleared/18218925/).

name: Peter J. Roskam
allegation: accepting impermissible travel gifts in 2011
text: In 2013 Roskam was investigated for accepting impermissible travel gifts in 2011. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded that there was insufficient evidence to show that the travel was improper](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt266/CRPT-113hrpt266.pdf).

name: William L. Owens
allegation: accepting impermissible travel gifts in 2011
text: In 2012 Owens was investigated for accepting impermissible travel gifts in 2011. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that the gift was impermissible, but since Owens repaid the funds, [the investigation was closed](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt266/CRPT-113hrpt266.pdf). Owens did not seek reelection in 2014.

name: John F. Tierney
allegation: failing to declare his wife's income of $40,000 to $160,000 from 2007-2010 to Congress and to the IRS because Tierney claimed it was actually a gift from his brother-in-law
text: In 2013 Tierney was investigated for failing to declare his wife's income of $40,000 to $160,000 from 2007-2010 to Congress and the IRS because Tierney claimed it was actually a gift from his brother-in-law. The House Committee on Ethics concluded that there was insufficient evidence to show that the funds were income and not gifts and that [no further action was needed](https://www.congress.gov/113/crpt/hrpt208/CRPT-113hrpt208.pdf). In 2010, Representative Tierney's wife [pleaded guilty to tax evasion also related to her brother's income](http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-rep-tierneys-wife-to-plead-guilty-to-tax-charges-2010oct05-story.html). In 2014, Representative Tierney was defeated in the Democratic primary.

name: Silvestre Reyes
allegation: improper use of campaign funds for personal use
text: In 2012 Reyes was investigated for improper use of campaign funds for personal use. The House Committee on Ethics [published the Office of Congressional Ethics Report and Findings and the member's response](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-ot-chairman-and-ranking-member-committee-ethics-regarding-representative). Reyes lost the 2012 election and the House Committe on Ethics' jurisdiction end with the member's term.

name: Shelley Berkley
allegation: advocating for programs in which she had a financial interest from 2008-2010
text: In 2012 Berkley was investigated for advocating for programs in which she had a financial interest from 2008-2010. The House Committee on Ethics [found that the representative had indeed advocated for some programs in which she had a financial interest](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt716/CRPT-112hrpt716.pdf). In 2012, Representative Berkley lost reelection.

name: Gregory W. Meeks
allegation: failing to disclose a gift in 2007 and receiving a loan on terms not available to the general public in 2010
text: In 2011 Meeks was investigated for failing to disclose a gift in 2007 and receiving a loan on terms not available to the general public in 2010. The House Committee on Ethics dismissed the loan allegation, but found the representative [unknowingly failed to properly disclose the gifts](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt709/CRPT-112hrpt709.pdf).

name: Tim Ryan
allegation: public intoxication
text: In 2012 Ryan was investigated for charges of public intoxication in 2012. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded no action was required as the charges were dismissed](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt710/CRPT-112hrpt710.pdf).

name: Jesse L. Jackson Jr.
allegation: misuse of campaign funds after a 2009 investigation by the Office of Congressional Ethics had investigated allegations that he had bought his appointment to Congress from Rod Blagojevich
text: In 2013, Jackson pleaded guilty to [misuse of campaign funds](http://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/21/us/politics/jesse-l-jackson-jr-pleads-guilty-to-wire-and-mail-fraud.html) after resigning from Congress in 2012. He also said that the 2008 attempt to purchase the former Senate seat of President Obama, for which he was investigated by Congress was done without his knowledge.

name: Wu
allegation: sexual assault
text: In July 2011, Wu was [accused of sexual assault](http://www.oregonlive.com/politics/index.ssf/2011/07/rep_david_wu_accused_of_aggres.html) and in Aug. 2011, he resigned.

name: Rod Blagojevich
allegation: corruption including selling the Senate seat vacated by Barack Obama after Obama won the 2008 presidential election
text: In 2011, Blagojevich, a former representative for IL-5, was [convicted of a broad range of corruption](https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/28/us/28blagojevich.html) as Governor of Illinois which included attempting to sell the appointment to the Senate seat vacated by Barack Obama after Obama won the 2008 presidential election. In 2020, President Trump [commuted Blagojevich's sentence](https://www.npr.org/2020/02/18/807117741/president-trump-offers-clemency-to-blagojevich-kerik-milken-others) and on Feb. 19, 2020, he was released from jail.

name: Maxine Waters
allegation: a conflict of interest with respect to meetings with a bank in which she had a financial interest
text: In 2009 Waters was investigated for a conflict of interest with respect to meetings with a bank in which she had a financial interest. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded that Representative Waters' chief of staff was at fault for creating the appearance of conflict, but Waters was not](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt690/CRPT-112hrpt690.pdf).

name: Vern Buchanan
allegation: failing to report positions he held with outside companies and to report unearned income from 2007 to 2010
text: In 2011 Buchanan was investigated for failing to report positions he held with outside companies and to report unearned income from 2007 to 2010. The House Committee on Ethics [concluded that the representative unknowingly failed to disclose positions in outside companies and unearned income](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt588/CRPT-112hrpt588.pdf). They were satisfied when the representative amended his forms.

name: Tom Coburn
allegation: meeting with a lobbyist before the one year embargo on former Congressional staffers' lobbying expired
text: In 2012 Coburn received a qualified admonishment for meeting with a lobbyist before the one year embargo on former Congressional staffers' lobbying expired. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics [issued a qualified admonishment because Coburn acknowledged his error and it was only a single meeting](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/letterstomembers?ID=4E526F44-3316-4700-B545-98017020C1FE). The [lobbyist in question](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Coburn#Affiliation_with_The_Family_and_John_Ensign) was the husband of a Sen. John Ensign staffer with whom Ensign had had an affair. Ensign attempted to placate the husband with a lobbying job and Coburn met with the husband before the lobbying embargo had ended. Coburn retired from the Senate in 2015.

name: David Vitter
allegation: demanding the issuance Gulf of Mexico deep water permits from the Secretary of the Interior in exchange for dropping his block on a proposed salary increase for the Secretary
text: In 2012 Vitter was investigated for demanding the issuance Gulf of Mexico deep water permits from the Secretary of the Interior in exchange for dropping his block on a proposed salary increase for the Secretary. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics [dismissed the charges because there did not appear to be any Senate rule or any law in place prohibiting Vitter's actions](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/files/serve?File_id=BA27F460-6CF2-4330-9455-84CF04C8B8E7). In 2014, Senator Vitter lost the election for Louisiana Governor and did not run again for the Senate.

name: Don Young
allegation: accepting campaign contributions in excess of legal limits
text: In 2011 Young was investigated for accepting campaign contributions in excess of legal limits. The House Committee on Ethics [dismissed the allegations, but also changed House rules to prohibit similar contributions in the future ](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt336/CRPT-112hrpt336.pdf).

name: Luis V. Gutiérrez
allegation: arrest during a protest outside of the White House in 2011
text: In 2011 Gutiérrez was investigated for having been arrested during a protest outside of the White House in 2011. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended no action as the fine has been paid](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt192/CRPT-112hrpt192.pdf). On November 28, 2017, Representative Gutiérrez announced he would not seek reelection to Congress.

name: Jean Schmidt
allegation: receiving over $500,000 in gifts as legal services without having established a legal services fund as required and for failing to properly disclose the gifts
text: In 2011 Schmidt was investigated for receiving over $500,000 in gifts as legal services without having established a legal services fund as required and for failing to properly disclose the gifts. The House Committee on Ethics [found the legal services were impermissble and that the representative was unaware of this, but that the committee would be satisfied if the representative properly disclosed and paid for the services](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt195/CRPT-112hrpt195.pdf). In 2012, Schmidt lost reelection. When she left office, [she had not paid for those services](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Schmidt#Legal_Expense_Fund).

name: Eric Massa
allegation: sexual harassment
text: In 2010 Massa was investigated for [sexual harassment](http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/04/13/AR2010041302257.html), at some point after he resigned on March 8, 2010, the Congressional [Office of Compliance](http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/congress-secretly-paid-100000-settle-harassment-claims-disgraced/story?id=51494871) settled with Massa's accusor for $100,000.

name: John Ensign
allegation: violating lobbying rules in order to cover up an affair
text: In 2011 Ensign was investigated for violating lobbying rules in order to cover up an affair. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics [referred the matter to the Department of Justice and the Federal Election Commission](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/pressreleases?ID=451C2D6E-643F-4026-B7C4-3F6587FCC2DC). Senator Ensign resigned May 3, 2011. The Department of Justice dropped its case in 2010 as did the FEC. However, the FEC reopened it after the Senate's report in 2011 and [levied fines in 2013](https://m.lasvegassun.com/news/2013/may/24/fec-fine-sad-end-sad-sage-ensign/).

name: Joseph Crowley
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions from entities affected by legislation then under consideration in 2009
text: In 2010 Crowley was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions from entities affected by legislation then under consideration in 2009. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended no further action](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-and-report-chair-and-ranking-member-regarding-representatives-john-campbell).

name: Tom Price
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions from entities affected by legislation then under consideration in 2009
text: In 2010 Price was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions from entities affected by legislation then under consideration in 2009. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended no further action](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-and-report-chair-and-ranking-member-regarding-representatives-john-campbell). In January 2017, Price left Congress to become Heath and Human Services Secretary. On September 29, 2017, [Price resigned](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/29/us/politics/tom-price-trump-hhs.html) due to inappropriate use of private and chartered flights while HHS Secretary.

name: John Campbell
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions from entities affected by legislation then under consideration in 2009
text: In 2010 Campbell was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions from entities affected by legislation then under consideration in 2009. The House Committee on Ethics [recommended no further action](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-and-report-chair-and-ranking-member-regarding-representatives-john-campbell). In 2014, Campell announced he would not seek reelection.

name: G. K. Butterfield
allegation: keeping the difference between his requested travel per diems and the amount he actually spent
text: In 2010 Butterfield was investigated for keeping the difference between his requested travel per diems and the amount he actually spent. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [recommended no further action](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-and-report-chair-and-ranking-republican-member-regarding-representatives).

The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [recommended no further action](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-and-report-chair-and-ranking-republican-member-regarding-representatives). In 2012, Representative Ortiz lost reelection.

The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [recommended no further action](https://ethics.house.gov/press-release/statement-and-report-chair-and-ranking-republican-member-regarding-representatives).

name: Charles B. Rangel
allegation: ethics violations and tax evasion
text: The House [voted to censure Rangel for ethics violations and tax evasion on December 2, 2010 by 333-79](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/111-2010/h607). In 2016, Representative Rangel did not seek reelection.

name: Joe Wilson
allegation: heckled President Obama during an address to Congress by yelling "You lie!"
text: In September 2009, Rep. Wilson heckled President Obama during an address to Congress by yelling "You lie!". A week later, the [House reprimanded him, 240-179](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/111-2009/h699).

name: Laura Richardson
allegation: violating gift and financial disclosure rules with respect to her home, its foreclosure and yard work from 2007 to 2008
text: In 2009 Richardson was investigated for violating gift and financial disclosure rules with respect to her home, its foreclosure and yard work from 2007 to 2008. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [concluded that Representative Richardson did not knowingly receive and/or fail to disclose gifts with respect to her home, its foreclosure or yard work](https://www.congress.gov/112/crpt/hrpt642/CRPT-112hrpt642.pdf). In 2012, Representative Richardson lost her bid for reelection in 2012.

name: Nathan Deal
allegation: improper influence over state officials to his financial benefit and failure to accurately disclose his earnings
text: In 2010 Deal was investigated for improper influence over state officials to his financial benefit and failure to accurately disclose his earnings. The House Office of Congressional Ethics [recommended further review](https://oce.house.gov/reports/investigations/oce-referral-regarding-former-rep-deal). Deal subsequently resigned.

name: Donna M. Christensen
allegation: receiving impermissible travel gifts
text: In 2009 Christensen was investigated for receiving impermissible travel gifts. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [concluded Representative Christensen did not knowingly accept impermissble travel gifts](https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/111th-congress/house-report/422). In 2014, Christensen did not seek reelection.

name: Carolyn Kilpatrick
allegation: receiving impermissible travel gifts
text: In 2009 Kilpatrick was investigated for receiving impermissible travel gifts. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [concluded Representative Kilpatrick did not knowingly accept impermissble travel gifts](https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/111th-congress/house-report/422). In 2010, Representative Kilpatrick lost the Democratic primary.

name: Donald Payne
allegation: receiving impermissible travel gifts
text: In 2009 Payne was investigated for receiving impermissible travel gifts. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [concluded Representative Payne did not knowingly accept impermissble travel gifts](https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/111th-congress/house-report/422).

name: Charles B. Rangel
allegation: receiving impermissible travel gifts
text: In 2009 Rangel was investigated for receiving impermissible travel gifts. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [concluded Rangel did knowingly accept impermissble travel gifts and ordered him to repay them](https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/111th-congress/house-report/422).

name: Bennie G. Thompson
allegation: receiving impermissible travel gifts
text: In 2009 Thompson was investigated for receiving impermissible travel gifts. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [concluded Thompson did not knowingly accept impermissble travel gifts](https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/111th-congress/house-report/422).

name: Todd Tiahrt
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes
text: In 2009 Tiahrt was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt423/CRPT-111hrpt423.pdf). In 2010, Representative Tiahrt ran for the Senate and lost.

name: Peter J. Visclosky
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes
text: In 2009 Visclosky was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt423/CRPT-111hrpt423.pdf).

name: Norman D. Dicks
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes
text: In 2009 Dicks was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt423/CRPT-111hrpt423.pdf). In 2012, Dicks did not seek reelection.

name: Marcy Kaptur
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes
text: In 2009 Kaptur was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt423/CRPT-111hrpt423.pdf).

name: James P. Moran
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes
text: In 2009 Moran was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt423/CRPT-111hrpt423.pdf). In 2014, Representative Moran announced he would not seek reelection.

name: John Murtha
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes
text: In 2009 Murtha was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt423/CRPT-111hrpt423.pdf). On February 8, 2010, Representative Murtha died.

name: C. W. Bill Young
allegation: soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes
text: In 2009 Young was investigated for soliciting campaign contributions in exchange for legislative outcomes. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt423/CRPT-111hrpt423.pdf). On October 18, 2013, Representative Young died.

name: Fortney Pete Stark
allegation: claiming tax credits for a residence which was not his primary residence
text: In 2009 Stark was investigated for claiming tax credits for a residence which was not his primary residence. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges as Representative Stark neither sought credits improperly nor did he receive them](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt409/CRPT-111hrpt409.pdf). In 2012, Representative Stark announced his retirement from Congress.

name: Roland Burris
allegation: quid pro quo with Rod Blagojevich with respect to Blagojevich's brother's campaign and Burris's senate appointment
text: In 2009 Burris received a qualified admonishment for appearing to agree to a quid pro quo with Rod Blagojevich with respect to Blagojevich's brother's campaign and Burris's senate appointment. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics [issued a qualified admonishment because while they did not find evidence of crimes, Burris' own comments were misleading with respect to what he promised in exchange for his senate appointment](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/files/serve?File_id=75733369-12F4-4A65-B71C-C71276547255). [Senator Burris served in the Senate only 9 months](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roland_Burris#Senate_appointment), with Mark Kirk winning the 2010 election.

name: Sam Graves
allegation: inviting improper hearing witnesses
text: In 2009 Graves was investigated for inviting improper hearing witnesses. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the charges as Representative Graves did not act improperly](https://www.congress.gov/111/crpt/hrpt320/CRPT-111hrpt320.pdf).

name: Kent Conrad
allegation: receiving mortgages from Countrywide Financial in violation of Senate gift rules
text: In 2009 Conrad was investigated for receiving mortgages from Countrywide Financial in violation of Senate gift rules. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics [dismssed the charges because the loans were not part of a program specifically benefiting senators](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/files/serve?File_id=EFD5E787-06EC-4B18-A249-5F0C1F7CC995). In 2012, Conrad did not run for reelection.

name: Christopher Dodd
allegation: receiving mortgages from Countrywide Financial in violation of Senate gift rules
text: In 2009 Dodd was investigated for receiving mortgages from Countrywide Financial in violation of Senate gift rules. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics [dismssed the charges because the loans were not part of a program specifically benefiting senators](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/letterstomembers?ID=9A93B548-9849-45B1-944B-C224F9A8DF85). In 2010, Senator Dodd did not run for reelection.

name: Mahoney
allegation: sexual harassment
text: In Oct. 2008 Rep. Mahoney was [accused of paying off an ex-staffer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Mahoney#Residency_and_Sex_Scandals) to head off a sexual harassment lawsuit. The next month he lost the election.

name: Rick Renzi
allegation: personal gain in a land swap deal
text: In 2013 Renzi was convicted for allegations of personal gain in a land swap deal. The House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [deferred to the Department of Justice](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/documents/Press%20Statement%20Renzi.pdf). Representative Renzi did not run for reelection in 2008 and in 2013 Renzi was convicted and was sentenced to serve three years in prison.

name: David Vitter
allegation: hiring prostitutes
text: In 2008 Vitter was investigated for hiring prostitutes. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics [dismissed the charges because the solicitation happened before his Senate term, did not involve public funds and did not result in criminal charges](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/letterstomembers?ID=4609ED24-76A6-40DD-AF03-33131E8A284C). In 2014, Senator Vitter lost the election for Louisiana Governor and did not run again for the Senate.

name: Pete Domenici
allegation: attempting to influence a federal investigation
text: In 2008 Domenici received a qualified admonishment for attempting to influence a federal investigation. Senate Select Committee on Ethics [issued a qualified admonishment because while they found no evidence of wrongdoing, the senator should have known how it would look](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/letterstomembers?ID=2AC523B2-7968-4C2F-8221-D6F21187B6E4). In 2007, Senator Domenici announced he would retire from the Senate in 2008 at the end of his term.

name: Larry Craig
allegation: using his status to receive special treatment and using campaign funds to pay legal expenses stemming from an arrest and guilty plea on disorderly conduct at the Minneapolis-St. Paul airport
text: In 2007 Craig pleaded guilty to using his status to receive special treatment and using campaign funds to pay legal expenses stemming from an arrest and guilty plea on disorderly conduct at the Minneapolis-St. Paul airport. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics [admonished the senator on both counts](https://www.ethics.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/files/serve?File_id=ED41D9EA-3E36-4D89-9FAC-8CABA610D07A). In 2007, Senator Craig was arrested for lewd conduct, pleaded to disorderly conduct and subsequently attempted to withdraw his guilty plea. He retired at the end of his term in 2008 and [as of 2016](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Larry_Craig#2007_arrest_and_consequences) has been ordered to personally pay for legal fees incurred that had previously been paid with campaign funds.

name: Ted Stevens
allegation: making false statements
text: In 2008 Stevens was convicted of making false statements. Prior to sentencing in 2009, the indictment was dismissed. Stevens lost the 2008 election and died in 2010.

name: Foley
allegation: sexual abuse of underage Congressional pages
text: In 2006, Foley faced allegations of [sexual abuse of underage Congressional pages](https://web.archive.org/web/20060930231243/http://blogs.abcnews.com/theblotter/2006/09/foley_resigns_o.html).
