In light of [Speaker Hastert's plan to expel him if he remained](http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/02/AR2006100200660.html), Foley [resigned on Sept. 29, 2006](https://web.archive.org/web/20060930231243/http://blogs.abcnews.com/theblotter/2006/09/foley_resigns_o.html). In 2008, the Florida Department of Law Enforcement [closed a criminal investigation](http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/09/19/foley.investigation/) without filing charges due to insufficient evidence.

name: Ney
allegation: involvement in the Jack Abramoff influence-peddling investigation
text: Ney faced an allegation of involvement in the Jack Abramoff influence-peddling investigation. On Aug. 14, 2006, he [withdrew from election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Ney#Electoral_history). On Oct. 3, 2006, he [pleaded guilty](http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/04/AR2006110400194.html). On Nov. 3, 2006, he [resigned](http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/04/AR2006110400194.html).

name: Cunningham
allegation: tax evasion, conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and wire fraud
text: Cunningham faced an allegation of tax evasion, conspiracy to commit bribery, mail fraud and wire fraud. On Jul. 14, 2005, he [announced he would not run for re-election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duke_Cunningham#Scandals_and_corruption). On Nov. 28, 2005, he [pleaded guilty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duke_Cunningham#Plea_agreement). On Nov. 28, 2005, he [resigned](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duke_Cunningham#Resignation).

name: McDermott
allegation: improperly disclosing the contents of an intercepted cell-phone conversation to the news media
text: On Dec. 28, 2004, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated McDermott for improperly disclosing the contents of an intercepted cell-phone conversation to the news media and established investigative subcommittee. On Dec. 8, 2006, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [concluded that McDermott’s conduct was inconsistent with the spirit of the applicable rules.](https://www.congress.gov/109/crpt/hrpt732/CRPT-109hrpt732.pdf).

name: Bell
allegation: filing a complaint against DeLay which contained innuendo, speculative assertions, or conclusory statements in violation of Committee Rule 15(a)(4)
text: On Nov. 18, 2004, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Bell for filing a complaint against DeLay which contained innuendo, speculative assertions, or conclusory statements in violation of Committee Rule 15(a)(4) and resolved the matter by a public letter. In 2004, Bell lost in the primary election.

name: McCarthy
allegation: conversion of campaign funds to personal use
text: On Nov. 18, 2004, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated McCarthy for conversion of campaign funds to personal use and issued a public statement finding McCarthy to be at fault, but did not pursue further when she resigned. In 2004, [McCarthy did not seek reelection after acknowledging that she had untreated alcoholism](http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/10/06/AR2010100606919.html).

name: DeLay
allegation: solicitation and receipt of campaign contributions in return for legislative assistance, use of corporate political contributions in violation of state law, and improper use of official resources for political purposes
text: On Oct. 6, 2004, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated DeLay for solicitation and receipt of campaign contributions in return for legislative assistance, use of corporate political contributions in violation of state law, and improper use of official resources for political purposes. They resolved the first and third allegations by public letter and the second allegation was deferred due to astate grand jury investigation. In 2005, he was [convicted of conspiring to influence Texas legislative races via a PAC using illegal corporate contributions](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2015/07/29/more-than-two-dozen-members-of-congress-have-been-indicted-since-1980/?utm_term=.49772980fe0c). In 2013, his conviction overturned.

name: DeLay
allegation: improperly linking personal interest of a member with effort achieve a legislative goal
text: On Oct. 4, 2004, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated DeLay for improperly linking the personal interest of a member with an effort to achieve a legislative goal and [issued a report finding DeLay's behavior inappropriate](https://www.congress.gov/108/crpt/hrpt722/CRPT-108hrpt722.pdf).

name: Miller
allegation: threatening to retaliate against a member for a particular vote
text: On Oct. 4, 2004, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Miller for threatening to retaliate against a member for a particular vote and [issued a report finding Miller's behavior inappropriate](https://www.congress.gov/108/crpt/hrpt722/CRPT-108hrpt722.pdf).

name: Smith
allegation: public statements impugning reputation of the House and failing to cooperate with the investigation
text: On Oct. 4, 2004, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Smith for public statements impugning the reputation of the House and failing to cooperate with the investigation. They [issued a report finding Smith's behavior inappropriate](https://www.congress.gov/108/crpt/hrpt722/CRPT-108hrpt722.pdf).

name: Janklow
allegation: vehicular manslaughter
text: Janklow faced an allegation of, on August 16, 2003, committing vehicular manslaughter. On Dec. 8, 2003, [convicted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Janklow#Vehicular_manslaughter). On Jan. 20, 2004, he [resigned](http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2003/12/08_hetlandc_janklow/).

name: Torricelli
allegation: violating Senate gift rules and creating the appearance of impropriety
text: On Jul. 30, 2002, the Senate Select Committee on Ethics investigated Torricelli for violating Senate gift rules and creating the appearance of impropriety and admonished him for creating the appearance of impropriety. In 2002, he did not run for reelection.

name: Traficant, Jr.
allegation: conspiracy to violate federal bribery and gratuity statutes, receipt of illegal gratuity, obstruction of justice, defrauding the government, racketeering, and tax evasion on April 11, 2002, for which he was convicted
text: On Jul. 18, 2002, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Traficant for conspiracy to violate federal bribery and gratuity statutes, receipt of illegal gratuities, obstruction of justice, defrauding the government, racketeering, and tax evasion for which he was convicted. The committee unanimously recommended expulsion. On Jul. 24, 2002, the House of Representatives [expelled Trafficant, 420-1](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/107-2002/h346).

name: Buyer
allegation: improper use of official resources for political purpose
text: On Aug. 1, 2001, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Buyer for improper use of official resources for political purpose and dismissed the complaint unanimously. A public letter was sent to Buyer.

name: Hilliard
allegation: improper loans made by campaign committee, improper campaign expenditures, and improper financial disclosure
text: On Jun. 20, 2001, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Hilliard for improper loans made by his campaign committee, improper campaign expenditures, and improper financial disclosure; and [issued a unanimously adopted letter of reproval](https://www.congress.gov/107/crpt/hrpt130/CRPT-107hrpt130.pdf) citing serious official misconduct. In 2002, he was defeated in the primary.

name: Shuster
allegation: relationship with a lobbyist (former chief of staff) and intervention with federal agencies on behalf of a constituent
text: On Oct. 4, 2000, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Shuster for a relationship with a lobbyist (former chief of staff) and intervention with federal agencies on behalf of a constituent; and [issued a unanimously adopted letter of reproval citing serious official misconduct](https://www.congress.gov/106/crpt/hrpt979/CRPT-106hrpt979.pdf).

name: Brown
allegation: lodging for member provided at premises owned or controlled by an imprisoned foreign national and gift of an automobile to Brown’s adult daughter in 1997.
text: On Sep. 21, 2000, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Brown for a gift of lodging for the member provided at premises owned or controlled by an imprisoned foreign national and a gift of an automobile to Brown’s adult daughter in 1997. The committe established an investigative subcommittee on June 9, 1999, the subcommittee recommended no further action and the full committee accepted the recommendation on Sept. 20, 2000. A press statement was released on Sept. 21, 2000.

name: Gingrich
allegation: violation of laws governing tax-exempt organizations, improper intervention with government agencies, receipt of improper personal benefits from a PAC and violation of campaign finance rules
text: In 1998, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Gingrich for violation of laws governing tax-exempt organizations, improper intervention with government agencies, receipt of improper personal benefits from a PAC and violation of campaign finance rules.

name: Kim
allegation: accepting illegal corporate and foreign contributions
text: On Oct. 6, 1998, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Kim for accepting illegal corporate and foreign contributions and [adopted a six count statement of alleged violations](https://www.congress.gov/105/crpt/hrpt797/CRPT-105hrpt797.pdf). On Aug. 11, 1997, he pleaded guilty in federal court. On Jun. 2, 1998, he was defeated in the primary.

name: DeLay
allegation: improperly linking campaign contributions to official actions and improper political favors for DeLay’s brother, a registered lobbyist
text: In 1997, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated DeLay for improperly linking campaign contributions to official actions and improper political favors for DeLay’s brother, a registered lobbyist, and [dismissed complaint](https://www.congress.gov/105/crpt/hrpt848/CRPT-105hrpt848.pdf). On Nov. 11, 1997, a private letter was sent to DeLay and a press statement released.

name: Cooley
allegation: lying to voters about his military service in official state voter guides
text: Cooley faced an allegation of lying to voters about his military service in official state voter guides. On Mar. 19, 1997, he was [convicted, ordered to pay a fine, and placed on two years' probation](http://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/us/former-congressman-is-convicted-of-lying.html). On Aug. 7, 1996, he [did not run for re-election](https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zHMVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NesDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5860%2C1623774).

name: Gingrich
allegation: improper use of official resources in preparation of a college course, conflict of interest, and improper use of tax-exempt entities in support of college course; investigation expanded to 1) false statements to committee on Standards, 2) relationship with foundation/course in violation of foundation’s tax-exempt status under Section 501(c)3 of the IRS Code, 3) use of unofficial resources for official purposes, and 4) activities and relationship with another foundation
text: On Jan. 17, 1997, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Gingrich for improper use of official resources in preparation of a college course, conflict of interest, and improper use of tax-exempt entities in support of college course. The investigation was expanded to 1) false statements to the Committee on Standards, 2) his relationship with the foundation/course in violation of foundation’s tax-exempt status under Section 501(c)3 of the IRS Code, 3) his use of unofficial resources for official purposes, and 4) his activities and relationship with another foundation. The committee investigated and dismissed the first two allegations (Gingrich made restitution to pay for the use of the official resources). On Jan. 21, 1997, the House of Representatives [reprimanded Gingrich and directed him to reimburse $300,000, 395-28](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/105-1997/h8).

name: Rose-Collins
allegation: misuse official resources, campaign resources and scholarship funds
text: On Jan. 2, 1997, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Rose-Collins for misuse of official resources, campaign resources, and scholarship funds. On Sept. 12, 1996 11-count statement of alleged violation was adopted, but the [subcommittee recommended that no further action be taken](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt876/CRPT-104hrpt876.pdf) due to pending loss of jurisdiction since Rose-Collins was defeated in the August primary.

name: Gephardt
allegation: inadequate financial disclosure on a series of land sales and financial agreements regarding property purchased and exchanged in North Carolina
text: On Sep. 28, 1997, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Gephardt for inadequate financial disclosure on a series of land sales and financial agreements regarding property purchased and exchanged in North Carolina. The committee [dismissed the complaint](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf).

name: McDermott
allegation: conflict of interest (participated in committee deliberations involving complaints filed with the substantial assistance of a - person affiliated with his political action committee) and violation of committee confidentiality rules
text: On Jul. 24, 1996, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated McDermott for conflict of interest (he participated in committee deliberations involving complaints filed with the substantial assistance of a person affiliated with his political action committee) and violation of committee confidentiality rules. The committee [dismissed the complaint](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf).

name: Gringrich
allegation: improper use of services of volunteer in congressional office
text: In 1996, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Gringrich for improper use of services of volunteer in congressional office via a complaint known as the Third Miller Complaint. The [charges were dismissed](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf) on Sep. 19, 1996.

name: Solomon
allegation: retaliation for political disagreement
text: In 1996, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Solomon for a press release and letter sent to a New York state assemblyman which included language that implied possible retaliation for political disagreement. On May. 8, 1996, the [complaint was dismissed](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf) after Solomon indicated he had not retaliated and had never intended to retaliate.

name: Bonior
allegation: improper use of congressional employees with regard to book published by Bonior in 1984 and improper salary payments to member of staff prior to her marriage to him
text: On May. 9, 1996, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Bonior for improper use of congressional employees with regard to a book published by Bonior in 1984 and improper salary payments to member of staff prior to her marriage to him. On May. 8, 1996, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the second complaint](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf). On May. 9, 1996, the committee returned the first complaint because the alleged violations occurred before the third previous Congress.

name: Gingrich
allegation: improper use of services of volunteer in congressional offices
text: On Mar. 29, 1996, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Gingrich for the improper use of the services of a volunteer in congressional offices and [concluded that the volunteer service, which had terminated by the time of the complaint, did not comply with the applicable guidelines](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf).

name: Torricelli
allegation: using congressional fax machine to send a press release having a political purpose (accusation made by Zimmer)
text: In 1996, in an accusation made by Zimmer, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Torricelli for using congressional fax machine to send a press release having a political purpose. On Mar. 29, 1996, the committee [determined use of the fax machine violated applicable rules](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf) on use of official resources and Torricelli reimbursed the use of the fax. On Nov. 5, 1996, Zimmer lost his bid for a New Jersey Senate seat to Torricelli.

name: Zimmer
allegation: using congressional fax machine for non-official purpose, specifically to send a press release entitled "Zimmer Wallops Torricelli in N.J. Congressional Softball Tourney" which was a personal attack and therefore violated usage rules (accusation made by Torricelli)
text: In 1996, based on an accusation made by Torricelli, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Zimmer for using a congressional fax machine for a non-official purpose, specifically to send a press release entitled "Zimmer Wallops Torricelli in N.J. Congressional Softball Tourney" which was alleged to be a personal attack and therefore a violation of usage rules. The complaint was returned on Jan. 5, 1996 for failing to meet standards of committee procedures and subsequently rel-submitted. The complaint was [dismissed](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf) on March 29, 1996 for lack of merit. On Nov. 5, 1996, Zimmer lost his bid for a New Jersey Senate seat to Torricelli.

name: McIntosh
allegation: distributing at a committee meeting and displaying on House floor a document attributed to an outside group that was instead created by representative's staff and allowing subcommittee staff to improperly question a witness regarding their observance of a religious holiday
text: On Mar. 14, 1996, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated McIntosh for distributing at a committee meeting and displaying on the House floor a document attributed to an outside group that was instead created by his staff and allowing subcommittee staff to improperly question a witness regarding their observance of a religious holiday. The committee [sent a letter](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf) to McIntosh on March 14, 1996 indicating that forging an outside organization's letterhead for staff-created documents was inappropriate as was any questioning of a witness's religious observances. On Mar. 14, 1996, McIntosh apologized and formalized a written policy for his staff regarding harassing, insensitive or discriminatory behavior. The committee voted not to make letter public, 5-4 on March 20, 1996.

name: Tucker
allegation: seven counts of extortion and two counts of tax evasion for extorting $30,000 from a local businessman while he was mayor of Compton, CA and failing to report payments on his taxes, for which he was convicted on December 8, 1995
text: Tucker faced an allegation of seven counts of extortion and two counts of tax evasion for extorting $30,000 from a local businessman while he was mayor of Compton, CA and failing to report payments on his taxes, for which he was convicted on Dec. 8, 1995. On Dec. 12, 1995, Sensenbrenner announced his intention to bring a resolution of expulsion to the floor of the House of Representatives [See Congressional Record](https://www.congress.gov/crec/1995/12/12/CREC-1995-12-12.pdf). On the same day, Tucker announced his resignation effective Dec. 15, 1995.

name: Gingrich
allegation: improper statements on House floor for political reasons; official resources used for political purposes
text: In 1995, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Gingrich for improper statements on House floor for political reasons and using official resource for political purposes. The complaints were [dismissed](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt401/CRPT-104hrpt401.pdf) in a public letter on Dec. 6, 1995 and a public report issued on Dec. 12, 1995.

name: Gingrich
allegation: accepting free cable television coverage of college lectures (improper gifts/solicitation)
text: In 1995, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Gingrich for accepting free cable television coverage of college lectures  as improper gifts/solicitation. The complaint was [dismissed](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt401/CRPT-104hrpt401.pdf) in a public letter on Dec. 6, 1995 and a public report issued on Dec. 12, 1995.

name: Gingrich
allegation: improperly using services of volunteer for official purposes
text: In 1995, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Gingrich for improperly using the services of a volunteer for official purposes in a complaint known as the First Miller Complaint. The committee found violations and sent a public letter to Gingrich and took no further action on Dec. 6, 1995. The committee [published its report](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt401/CRPT-104hrpt401.pdf) on Dec. 12, 1995.

name: Gingrich
allegation: the allegations in “First Jones Complaint”  plus improper receipt of book royalties for To Renew America, improper book auction, conflict of interest, improper solicitation, improper use of official resources, and improper intervention with federal authorities
text: In 1995, Gingrich faced the allegations in “First Jones Complaint” plus improper receipt of book royalties for To Renew America, improper book auction, conflict of interest, improper solicitation, improper use of official resources, and improper intervention with federal authorities. On Dec. 6, 1995, the complaint was dismissed. On Dec. 22, 1995, the House of Representatives [adopted the committee resolution on restricting advances from book contracts but not subjecting royalty income to outside earned income limit, 259-128](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/104-1995/h883).

name: Packwood
allegation: sexual misconduct and abuse of power
text: On Sep. 5, 1995, the Senate Select Committee on Ethics investigated Packwood for sexual misconduct and abuse of power and recommended expulsion from the Senate. On Sep. 8, 1995, he [resigned](http://articles.latimes.com/1995-09-08/news/mn-43532_1_senator-packwood-resigns).

name: Wilson
allegation: improper use of campaign funds and inadequate financial disclosure
text: Wilson faced an allegation of improper use of campaign funds and inadequate financial disclosure. On Aug. 25, 1995, the Federal Elections Commission (FEC) transmitted information to the committee on Standards developed during an investigation On Dec. 7, 1995, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [dismissed the complaint and issued a letter released publicly after Wilson admitted his error and paid a $90,000 fine](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf).

name: Reynolds
allegation: misuse of congressional staff for personal purposes, misuse of official resources, failure to repay personal debts and obstruction of justice; later convicted in state court of criminal sexual assault, aggravated sexual abuse, solicitation of child pornography and obstruction of justice on Aug. 22, 1995
text: On Jun. 28, 1995, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Reynolds for misuse of congressional staff for personal purposes, misuse of official resources, failure to repay personal debts and obstruction of justice. He was later convicted in state court of criminal sexual assault, aggravated sexual abuse, solicitation of child pornography and obstruction of justice on Aug. 22, 1995. On Sep. 1, 1995, he resigned. On Sep. 28, 2017, the U.S. District Court [convicted him on four misdemeanor counts alleging he failed to file a federal income tax return for four consecutive years](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mel_Reynolds#Later_career).

name: Armey
allegation: improper use of congressional stationery
text: In 1995, Armey faced an allegation of improper use of congressional stationery. On Jun. 2, 1995, Guitierrez filed a complaint on behalf of the Congressional Accountability Project. Armey admitted to the violation and the complaint was dismissed on June 13, 1995. [A public letter to Armey and a press statement were released on June 14, 1995](https://www.congress.gov/104/crpt/hrpt886/CRPT-104hrpt886.pdf).

name: Frost
allegation: using congressional staff for redistricting work [R. 45]; campaign contributions by congressional staff (18 U.S.C. § 603)
text: In 1994, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Frost for using congressional staff for redistricting work and campaign contributions by congressional staff. On Nov. 29, 1994, the complaint was dismissed and a public letter was released indicating that the committee found a technical violation of campaign regulations. Frost agreed to appropriate reimbursement.

name: Durenberger
allegation: misuse of public funds while in office
text: Durenberger faced an allegation of misuse of public funds while in office. On Aug. 22, 1995, he [pleaded guilty to five misdemeanor charges of abuse of a Congressional expense account](http://www.nytimes.com/1995/08/23/us/ex-senator-is-guilty-of-expense-abuses.html).

name: Rostenkowski
allegation: mail fraud, wire fraud, witness tampering, concealing a material fact, false statements, embezzlement, and conspiracy, for which he was indicted
text: Rostenkowski faced allegations of mail fraud, wire fraud, witness tampering, concealing a material fact, false statements, embezzlement, and conspiracy, for which he was indicted. On Jun. 30, 1994, member complaint was filed. On Aug. 17, 1994, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct deferred action at request of U.S. Attorney On Nov. 8, 1994, he defeated for reelection. On Apr. 10, 1996, he [pleaded guilty to mail fraud](http://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/10/us/rostenkowski-pleads-guilty-to-mail-fraud.html). On Dec. 23, 2000, he was [pardoned by President Clinton having already served 15 months in prison and two months in a halfway house in addition to paying a $100,000 fine](http://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/23/us/clinton-issues-a-pardon-to-ex-rep-rostenkowski.html).

name: Kolter
allegation: stealing money from the House Post Office
text: Kolter faced an allegation of stealing money from the House Post Office. On May. 8, 1996, he [pleaded guilty to one count of conspiring with the former House postmaster and others to steal from the office](https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1996/05/08/kolter-guilty-in-post-office-scandal/a712baa5-36e1-4bb8-8255-7bb7ebb373a7/?utm_term=.207492fec1cd).

name: Kay Bailey Hutchison
allegation: using state employees and time to conduct political and personal business while Texas State Treasurer
text: Kay Bailey Hutchison faced an allegation of using state employees and time to conduct political and personal business while Texas State Treasurer. On Feb. 12, 1994, [acquitted on all charges in state court after prosecuters refused to present their case against Hutchison due to concerns over admissability of evidence](http://www.nytimes.com/1994/02/12/us/fight-over-evidence-results-in-acquittal-of-senator-in-texas.html).

name: Fauntroy
allegation: stealing from the House Bank
text: Fauntroy faced an allegation of stealing from the House Bank. On Mar. 25, 1995, he [pleaded guilty to one count of violating the false statements statute regarding a charitable contribution](https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/Pre_96/March95/153.txt.html).

name: Bustamante
allegation: racketeering and bribery
text: Bustamante faced an allegation of racketeering and bribery. On Jul. 22, 1993, he was [convicted](http://www.nytimes.com/1993/07/22/us/federal-jury-convicts-ex-texas-congressman.html). In 1992, he lost his bid for re-election.

name: Mavroules
allegation: accepting illegal gifts and misusing his office for private gain
text: Mavroules faced an allegation of accepting illegal gifts and misusing his office for private gain. On Apr. 3, 1993, he [pleaded guilty and served 15 months in prison](http://www.nytimes.com/1993/08/03/us/ex-congressman-to-go-to-prison.html). In 1992, he lost the election.

name: Adams
allegation: rape and sexual harassment
text: In 1992, Adams was [accused of rape and sexual harassment](http://www.nytimes.com/1992/03/02/us/brock-adams-quits-senate-race-amid-sex-misconduct-allegations.html) and quit his Senate race as a result.

name: Perkins
allegation: bank fraud and lying to investigators
text: Perkins faced an allegation of bank fraud and lying to investigators. On Dec. 13, 1994, he [pleaded guilty](https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/Pre_96/December94/697.txt.html). In 1992, [perkins' district, the Kentucky 7th was eliminated by redistricting and Perkins did not seek re-election in the newly created 5th district in 1992](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_C._Perkins#Biography).

name: Hubbard
allegation: obstruction of justice and misappropriation of campaign funds involving the House Bank
text: Hubbard faced an allegation of obstruction of justice and misappropriation of campaign funds involving the House Bank. On Apr. 6, 1994, he [pleaded guilty](https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1994/04/06/guilty-plea-entered-in-bank-scandal/0b98374f-4133-4e78-af07-c47a4b6bfdcb/?utm_term=.5417f6473e72). In 1992, he lost the election.

name: Oakar
allegation: lying to the FBI, using the House Bank to convert public money to her own use
text: Oakar faced an allegation of lying to the FBI, using the House Bank to convert public money to her own use. On Sep. 30, 1997, she [pleaded guitly to two misdemeanors](http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-09-30/news/9709300278_1_plead-rep-mary-rose-oakar-false-names). In 1992, she was not re-elected.

name: Dyson
allegation: misuse of office funds and sex discrimination in hiring
text: On Jan. 31, 1990, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct dismissed allegations against Dyson for misuse of office funds and sex discrimination in hiring, having previously declined to consider the allegations when they were first lodged due to the proximity to election day in 1988.

name: Sikorksi
allegation: misuse of staff for personal errands
text: In 1990, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Sikorksi for misuse of staff for personal errands and on Jan. 31, 1990 the complaint was dismissed.

name: Alan Cranston
allegation: improperly intervening on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business
text: In 1989, Sen. Cranston (along with Sens. DeConcini, Glenn, McCain and Riegle) was accused of improperly intervening with federal banking regulators on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business. Because Keating's campaign contributions came so close in time to Cranston's actions, he was [reprimanded by the Senate Select Committee on Ethics in front of the full Senate](https://alamedamgr.files.wordpress.com/2018/04/cq-almanac-online-edition-keating-five.pdf). An odd aspect of Cranston's "punishment" was that he was allowed to rebut his reprimand on the floor of the Senate. To his colleagues' displeasure, he declared that [if he was guilty of wrongdoing, then so was the entire Senate](https://alamedamgr.files.wordpress.com/2018/04/cq-almanac-online-edition-keating-five.pdf). He did not run for re-election in 1992.

name: Dennis DeConcini
allegation: improperly intervening on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business
text: In 1989, Sen. DeConcini was accused of improperly intervening with federal banking regulators on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics published a report in which DeConcini was criticized for giving the appearance of impropriety, but not punished because he had not violated any Senate rules.

name: Donald Riegle, Jr.
allegation: improperly intervening on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business
text: In 1989, Sen. Riegle was accused of improperly intervening with federal banking regulators on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business. The Senate Select Committee on Ethics published a report in which Riegle was criticized for giving the appearance of impropriety, but not punished because he had not violated any Senate rules.

name: John Glenn
allegation: improperly intervening on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business
text: In 1989, Sen. Glenn was accused of improperly intervening with federal banking regulators on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business. In 1991, the Senate Select Committee on Ethics published a report in which charges were dismissed.

name: John McCain
allegation: improperly intervening on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business
text: In 1989, Sen. McCain was accused of improperly intervening with federal banking regulators on behalf of Charles Keating, Jr. and his savings and loan business. In 1991, the Senate Select Committee on Ethics published a report in which charges were dismissed even though they did indicate that McCain had demonstrated poor judgement in attending a meeting with federal regulators on Keating's behalf. McCain remained in the Senate until his death in 2018. In the intervening years, he [testified against Keating (the only one of the five to do so)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keating_Five#Aftermath) in a civil trial and became an [advocate of campaign finance reform](https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/article/2018/aug/31/sen-john-mccain-fought-clean-money-politics-are-we/).

name: Lukens
allegation: contributing to the unruliness of a female minor, e.g. sex with an underage girl on May 26, 1989, for which he was convicted as a misdemeanor; improper sexual advances to Capitol elevator operator on Oct. 17, 1990
text: Lukens faced an allegation of contributing to the unruliness of a female minor, e.g. sex with an underage girl on May 26, 1989, for which he was convicted as a misdemeanor; and of improper sexual advances to a Capitol elevator operator on Oct. 17, 1990.  On Oct. 4, 1990, he resigned. On Oct. 24, 1990, the preliminary inquiry resolution was amended to include the assertion of additional charges from Oct. 22, 1990. [The staff report was published on Oct. 24, 1990](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/comm_print_10241990.pdf).

name: Durenberger
allegation: a wide range of financial misconduct
text: Durenberger faced an allegation of a wide range of financial misconduct. On Jul. 25, 1990, the Senate [voted to denounce him, which appears to have been intended as a type of censure which acknowledges no ill intent](https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/common/censure_cases/141DavidDurenberger.htm).

name: Swindall
allegation: money laundering and lying to the FBI
text: Swindall faced an allegation of money laundering and lying to the FBI. In 1989, he was [convicted](http://articles.latimes.com/1994-02-12/news/mn-21903_1_pat-swindall). On Feb. 12, 1994, [started serving a one year prison sentence in a minimum-security federal prison after remaining free on bond while his appeals were active](http://articles.latimes.com/1994-02-12/news/mn-21903_1_pat-swindall).

name: Frank
allegation: 1) use of personal residence for prostitution by third parties, 2) improper contacts with probation office on behalf of personal assistant, 3) improper dismissal of assistant’s parking tickets, and 4) sexual activity in the House gymnasium
text: Frank faced an allegation of 1) use of personal residence for prostitution by third parties, 2) improper contacts with probation office on behalf of personal assistant, 3) improper dismissal of assistant’s parking tickets, and 4) sexual activity in the House gymnasium. Frank admitted preparing a memo containing misleading statements that could be perceived as an attempt to use political influence in a judicial matter and arranging improper dismissal of parking tickets for personal assistant. The committee recommended reprimand and restitution of parking tickets, [12-0 on July 20, 1990](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Hrpt101-610.pdf). On Jul. 26, 1990, he was [reprimanded, 408-18](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/101-1990/h271).

name: Gringrich
allegation: using book partnership to avoid outside income limits or to obtain impermissible gifts or contributions, improper use of official resources to prepare book, and inadequate financial disclosure
text: In 1990, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Gringrich for using book partnership to avoid outside income limits or to obtain impermissible gifts or contributions, improper use of official resources to prepare book, and inadequate financial disclosure. The committee issued a statement on Mar. 8, 1990.

name: Savage
allegation: improper sexual advances toward a female Peace Corps volunteer (March 1989)
text: Savage faced an allegation of improper sexual advances toward a female Peace Corps volunteer in March 1989. On Nov. 20, 1989, Savage apologized. On Jan. 31, 1990, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [issued a public report disapproving of his conduct, 12-0](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Hrpt101-397_0.pdf).

name: Garcia
allegation: conspiracy and Travel Act violations (receipt of $170,000 in payments, loan, and a diamond necklace from defense contractor), for which Garcia and his wife were convicted on Oct. 20, 1989, four counts of bribery and receipt of illegal gratuities, for which he was acquitted
text: In 1989, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Garcia for conspiracy and Travel Act violations (receipt of $170,000 in payments, loans, and a diamond necklace from a defense contractor), for which Garcia and his wife were convicted on Oct. 20, 1989, four counts of bribery and receipt of illegal gratuities, for which he was acquitted. On Jan. 7, 1990, he [resigned](http://articles.latimes.com/1990-01-03/news/mn-190_1_robert-garcia).

name: Bates
allegation: sexual harassment and improper campaign activity in congressional office
text: In 1989, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Bates for sexual harassment and improper campaign activity in congressional office. On Oct. 18, 1989, the committee adopted a public letter of reproval. In 1989, he [admitted to violations and wrote personal letter of apology](https://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/congress-took-three-decades-come-far-sexual-harassment-victim-says).

name: Wright, Jr.
allegation: improper lobbying efforts on behalf of a constituent with whom Rep. Wright had an interest in a private gas well, 2) intervention in a matter before the Department of the Interior on behalf of Texas Oil and Gas Company, 3) improper use of campaign funds to pay for publication of a book for which Wright received a 55% royalty (Reflections of a Public Man), 4) improper use of government resources on the book, 5) improper use of a condominium in Fort Worth, TX (free and below market housing from real estate developer George Mallick) and 6) exercise of undue influence with officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board on behalf of four Texas businessmen regarding the savings and loan crisis
text: In 1989, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Wright for improper lobbying efforts on behalf of a constituent with whom Wright had an interest in a private gas well, 2) intervention in a matter before the Department of the Interior on behalf of Texas Oil and Gas Company, 3) improper use of campaign funds to pay for publication of a book for which Wright received a 55% royalty (Reflections of a Public Man), 4) improper use of government resources on the book, 5) improper use of a condominium in Fort Worth, TX (free and below market housing from real estate developer George Mallick) and 6) exercise of undue influence with officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board on behalf of four Texas businessmen regarding the savings and loan crisis. On Apr. 17, 1989, the committee made the report of Special Outside Counsel public. On Jun. 30, 1989, [rep. Wright resigned as Speaker on House floor after having announced his intent to do so in May](https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/clinton/frenzy/wright.htm).

name: Biaggi
allegation: accepting illegal gratuities, obstruction of justice and violation of the Travel Act on Sept. 22, 1987 because he accepted free vacations in exchange for using influence, for which he was convicted
text: In 1988, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Biaggi for accepting illegal gratuities, obstruction of justice and violation of the Travel Act on Sept. 22, 1987 because he accepted free vacations in exchange for using influence, for which he was convicted. On Feb. 17, 1988 the committee recommended expulsion, 12-0. On Aug. 5, 1988, he [resigned after an additional conviction](http://articles.latimes.com/1988-08-05/news/mn-8579_1_mario-biaggi).

name: Rose III
allegation: borrowing campaign funds for personal use and inadequate financial disclosure
text: In 1988, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Rose for borrowing campaign funds for personal use and inadequate financial disclosure. On Mar. 23, 1988, the committee adopted a public letter of reproval, 9-3. In 1994, he [paid civil fine of $12,500](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Murphy
allegation: improper use of official resources and violation of House rules regarding voting
text: In 1987, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Murphy for improper use of official resources and violation of House rules regarding voting and recommended reprimand, 11-0. On Dec. 18, 1987, the House of Representatives [reprimanded him, 324-68](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/100-1987/h472).

name: Boner
allegation: violations of the gift rule, improper use of campaign funds, conflict of interest, and improper use of official resources
text: On Feb. 5, 1986, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct began investigating Boner for violations of the gift rule, improper use of campaign funds, conflict of interest, and improper use of official resources and preliminary inquiry authorized. On Apr. 23, 1987, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct deferred at DOJ request. On Sep. 23, 1987, [Boner was elected mayor of Nashville](http://www.nytimes.com/1987/09/23/us/congressman-elected-mayor.html). On Oct. 5, 1987, he resigned from Congress. On Dec. 14, 1987, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [staff report was published](https://ethics.house.gov/committee-report/staff-report-matter-representative-william-h-boner).

name: Stallings
allegation: improper use of campaign funds (loan to congressional employee)
text: In 1987, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Stallings for improper use of campaign funds (loan to congressional employee) and on Oct. 15, 1987, adopted a public letter of reproval, 12-0.

name: St. Germain
allegation: accepting free flights on corporate aircraft, intervening on behalf of an organization in which he had a financial interest and inadequate financial disclosure
text: In 1987, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated St. Germain for accepting free flights on corporate aircraft, intervening on behalf of an organization in which he had a financial interest and inadequate financial disclosure and, on Apr. 9, 1987, recommended no sanction.

name: Oakar
allegation: purchase of a townhouse with a member of her staff and improper salary disbursements to an employee
text: In 1987, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Oakar for purchase of a townhouse with a member of her staff and improper salary disbursements to an employee. An informal staff review of press allegations found improper payments but no fraudulent intent. The committee recommended no sanction and on Jun. 17, 1987, letter released publicly.

name: Weaver
allegation: borrowing approximately $82,000 in campaign funds for personal use and inadequate financial disclosure of commodity investment transactions
text: In 1987, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Weaver for borrowing approximately $82,000 in campaign funds for personal use and inadequate financial disclosure of commodity investment transactions and on Sep. 30, 1986 recommended no sanction.

name: Sweeney
allegation: use of official resources for political purposes and requiring congressional staff required to campaign as a condition of continued employment
text: On Sep. 11, 1986, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Sweeney for use of official resources for political purposes and requiring congressional staff to campaign as a condition of continued employment and determined that the campaign activities occurred in the district office with no evidence Sweeney directed or condoned the improper activities.

name: Daniel
allegation: accepting free flights on corporate aircraft (1983-85)
text: In 1986, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Daniel for accepting free flights on corporate aircraft (1983-85) and on Feb. 5, 1986 Daniel made restitution and amended the financial disclosure statement.

name: Ferraro
allegation: inadequate and improper financial disclosure
text: In 1984, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Ferraro for inadequate and improper financial disclosure. The committee found technical violations, but no sanction was recommended and a report was filed on Dec. 4, 1984.

name: Hansen
allegation: making false statements and failing to report nearly $334,000 in loans and profits from 1978-81
text: In 1984, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Hansen for making false statements and failing to report nearly $334,000 in loans and profits from 1978-81. On Jun. 20, 1984, the committee recommended reprimand, 11-1. On Jul. 31, 1984, the House of Representatives [reprimanded Hansen, 354-52](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/98-1984/h793). On Nov. 6, 1984, Hansen was [defeated in the election by Richard Stallings](http://www.nytimes.com/1984/11/09/us/justice-dept-rebuts-rep-hansen-of-idaho.html). In 1985, the [conviction was vacated, U.S. v. Hansen, 906 F. Supp. 688 (1995)](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Wilson
allegation: using cocaine and marijuana
text: In 1983, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Wilson for using cocaine and marijuana and preliminary inquiry voted; Special Counsel investigated and found no basis for statement of alleged violation. On Nov. 17, 1983, the committee took no further action.

name: Dellums
allegation: using cocaine and marijuana
text: In 1983, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Dellums for using cocaine and marijuana and preliminary inquiry voted; Special Counsel investigated and found no basis for statement of alleged violation. On Nov. 17, 1983, the committee took no further action.

name: Studds
allegation: sexual relationship with 17-year old male House page that occurred 10 years earlier in 1973
text: On Jul. 14, 1983, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Studds for sexual relationship with 17-year old male House page that occurred 10 years earlier in 1973 and recommended reprimand and filed report, 11-1. On Jul. 20, 1983, the House of Representatives [rejected the reprimand recommendation, 289-136; censured Studds instead, 420-3](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/98-1983/h246).

name: Crane
allegation: a sexual relationship with a 17-year old female House page in 1980
text: On Jul. 14, 1983, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Crane for a sexual relationship with a 17-year old female House page in 1980 and recommended reprimand, 11-1. On Jul. 20, 1983, the House of Representatives [rejected the reprimand recommendation, 289-136; censured him instead, 421-3](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/98-1983/h244). On Nov. 6, 1984, he was defeated in the election.

name: Richmond
allegation: evading federal taxes, two misdemeanors involving a government contract, and misdemeanor possession of marijuana on Aug 25, 1982
text: In 1982, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Richmond for evading federal taxes (pleaded guilty to felony charge), two misdemeanors involving a government contract, and misdemeanor possession of marijuana on Aug. 25, 1982. On May. 12, 1982, the committee deferred its investigation at the request of the Department of Justice. On Aug. 25, 1982, he [resigned](https://www.upi.com/Archives/1982/08/25/Millionaire-Congressman-Fred-Richmond-pleaded-guilty-to-tax-and/6183399096000/).

name: Murtha
allegation: bribery and conspiracy as part of ABSCAM investigation
text: In 1981, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Murtha for bribery and conspiracy as part of ABSCAM investigation. On Jul. 28, 1981, the charges were dismissed and the Special Counsel resigned.

name: Williams
allegation: bribery connected with the ABSCAM sting
text: Williams faced an allegation of bribery connected with the ABSCAM sting. On May. 1, 1981, he was convicted and the Senate Select Committee on Ethics opened an inquiry. On Sep. 3, 1981, the Senate Select Committee on Ethics filed its report. On Mar. 11, 1982, he [resigned to avoid an expulsion vote](https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/common/expulsion_cases/140HarrisonWilliams_expulsion.htm).

name: Hinson
allegation: arrested for engaging in sexual activity with a member of the same sex, then illegal in Washington, D.C.
text: In 1981, Hinson was arrested for engaging in sexual activity with a member of the same sex, then illegal in Washington, D.C. On Apr. 13, 1981, he [resigned](http://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/29/us/around-the-nation-hinson-pleads-no-contest-to-oral-sodomy-charge.html). On May. 28, 1981, he [pleaded no contest to charges of "attempted oral sodomy" in a House office building restroom](http://www.nytimes.com/1981/05/29/us/around-the-nation-hinson-pleads-no-contest-to-oral-sodomy-charge.html).

name: Kelly
allegation: bribery and conspiracy in the ABSCAM investigation
text: Kelly faced an allegation of bribery and conspiracy in the ABSCAM investigation. On Nov. 4, 1980, he lost the election. On Jan. 26, 1981, he was [convicted](http://www.nytimes.com/1981/01/27/us/ex-representive-kelly-convicted-of-abscam-bribery.html).

name: Murphy
allegation: taking an unlawful gratuity as part of ABSCAM investigation
text: Murphy faced an allegation of taking an unlawful gratuity as part of ABSCAM investigation. On Nov. 4, 1980, he [lost the election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_M._Murphy). On Dec. 3, 1980, he was [convicted](http://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/12/nyregion/7-from-congress-guilty-in-abscam.html).

name: Lederer
allegation: bribery, acceptance of an unlawful gratuity, conspiracy and Travel Act violations
text: Lederer resigned April 29, 1981 after the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [recommended expulsion](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Hrpt97-110.pdf), 10-2, following his conviction on charges of bribery. He was accused of bribery, acceptance of an unlawful gratuity, conspiracy and Travel Act violations.

name: Thompson
allegation: bribery charges in the ABSCAM investigation
text: Thompson was convicted in 1980 of bribery charges in the ABSCAM investigation.

name: Jenrette, Jr.
allegation: bribery and conspiracy for accepting money in return for promising to use official influence as part of ABSCAM investigation
text: Jenrette was convicted of bribery and conspiracy for accepting money in return for promising to use official influence as part of the ABSCAM investigation.

name: Myers
allegation: bribery, conspiracy and Travel Act violations as part of the ABSCAM investigation
text: Meyers was convicted of bribery in 1980 as part of the ABSCAM investigation and on Oct. 2, 1980, the House of Representatives [expelled him](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/96-1980/h1222) in a 376-30 vote.

name: Wilson
allegation: accepting money from a person with direct interest in legislation; maintaining a person on payroll not performing duties commensurate with pay; personal use of campaign funds
text: On Apr. 24, 1980, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Wilson for accepting money from a person with direct interest in legislation; maintaining a person on payroll not performing duties commensurate with pay; personal use of campaign funds and recommended censure and denial of chairmanship, 10-2. On Jun. 3, 1980, Wilson was [defeated in the primary](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf). On Jun. 10, 1980, the House of Representatives [agreed to an amendment deleting denial of chairmanship from sanction, 261-148; and censured Wilson by voice vote](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/96-1980/h949).

name: Flood
allegation: using official influence on behalf of private parties and foreign governments in return for unlawful payments
text: On Dec. 12, 1979, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Flood for using official influence on behalf of private parties and foreign governments in return for unlawful payments and disciplinary hearing deferred due to hospitalization. On Jan. 31, 1980, he [resigned](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf). On Feb. 26, 1980, he pleaded guilty to misdemeanor of conspiracy to defraud government. On Mar. 26, 1980, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct [filed its report](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Hrpt96-856.pdf).

name: Talmadge
allegation: financial misconduct
text: On Oct. 3, 1979, the Senate Select Committee on Ethics investigated Talmadge for financial misconduct and recommended that Talmadge be "denounced" (censured). On Oct. 11, 1979, the Senate [censured him](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/96-1979/s346). On Nov. 4, 1980, lost the election.

name: Diggs, Jr.
allegation: mail fraud and false statements
text: In October 1978, Diggs was convicted of taking kickbacks. He was re-elected the next month, but on July 31, 1979, the House of Representatives [censured him](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/96-1979/h366) in a 414-0 vote and in 1980 he [resigned after losing the criminal appeal](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Eilberg
allegation: conflict of interest by helping a hospital receive a federal grant
text: On Sep. 13, 1978, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Eilberg for conflict of interest by helping a hospital receive a federal grant and conducted inquiry. On Oct. 24, 1978, he was indicted. On Nov. 7, 1978, he lost the election.

name: Wilson
allegation: making a false statement on an answer to a Standards Committee questionnaire regarding the Korean Influence Investigation
text: On Sep. 27, 1978, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Wilson for making a false statement on an answer to a Standards Committee questionnaire regarding the Korean Influence Investigation and recommended reprimand, 8-1. On Oct. 13, 1978, the House of Representatives [reprimanded him, 329-41](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/95-1978/h1513).

name: McFall
allegation: failing to report $3,000 campaign contribution in 1974
text: On Oct. 4, 1978, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated McFall for failing to report $3,000 campaign contribution in 1974 and recommended reprimand, 8-2. On Oct. 13, 1978, the House of Representatives reprimanded him by voice vote On Dec. 31, 1978, he [resigned](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Roybal
allegation: failing to report campaign contributions, converting campaign funds to personal use, and making a false statement to the Standards committee
text: On Sep. 27, 1978, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Roybal for failing to report campaign contributions, converting campaign funds to personal use, and making a false statement to the Standards committee and recommended censure. On Oct. 13, 1978, the House of Representatives [rejected the censure recommendation, 219-170; but reprimanded him by voice vote](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/95-1978/h1514).

name: Patten
allegation: making political contributions with funds provided by another
text: On Oct. 4, 1978, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Patten for making political contributions with funds provided by another; conducted an inquiry; and dismissed the charges, 8-0.

name: Hinshaw
allegation: state bribery charges for conduct prior to election
text: On Jan. 26, 1976, Hinshaw was [convicted of state bribery charges](https://www.nytimes.com/1976/07/11/archives/hinshaw-expulsion-from-house-urged-conviction-is-cited.html) for conduct prior to election but the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct recommended against expulsion due to lack of jurisdiction for actions committed prior to service in House, 10-2.

name: Hayes
allegation: retaining employee on public payroll for immoral purposes (1974-76)
text: On Jun. 2, 1976, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Hayes for retaining an employee on public payroll for immoral purposes (1974-76) after Hays and other members requested an investigation of the press allegations. On Sep. 1, 1976, he [resigned prior to hearings](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Burke
allegation: on May 27, 1978, drunk and disorderly and resisting arrest at the Centerfold Bar in Dania, FL
text: On May 27, 1978, Burke faced an allegation of drunk and disorderly and resisting arrest at the Centerfold Bar in Dania, FL. Burke resisted, he said, because he was only there to stop a drug deal. In 1978, he [pleaded guilty and lost his bid for re-election](https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1993/06/18/j-herbert-burke-dies/d49b3e2e-208a-4eae-856f-f4e25e48a9f8/?utm_term=.55f18b71be87).

name: Tonry
allegation: stuffing ballot boxes and illegal campaign contributions in the primary election
text: Tonry faced an allegation of stuffing ballot boxes and illegal campaign contributions in the primary election. On May. 5, 1977, he [resigned](http://www.nytimes.com/1977/05/05/archives/rep-tonry-figure-in-vote-fraud-resigns-but-vows-to-run-again.html).

name: Sikes
allegation: improper financial disclosure [R. 44] and conflict of interest
text: On Jul. 21, 1976, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Sikes for improper financial disclosure [R. 44] and conflict of interest and recommended reprimand, 10-2. On Jul. 29, 1976, the House of Representatives [reprimanded him, 381-3](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/94-1976/h1042). In 1978, he [did not seek re-election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bob_Sikes#Reprimand).

name: Harrington
allegation: public disclosure of executive session testimony by the CIA Director to the House Armed Services Investigations Subcommittee (Apr. 22, 1974);
text: In 1975, the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct investigated Harrington for public disclosure of 1974 executive session testimony by the CIA Director to the House Armed Services Investigations Subcommittee. On Nov. 6, 1975, the committee dismissed the complaint because the information had not been properly classified.

name: Dowdy
allegation: conspiracy to violate a bribery statute and an obstruction of justice statute, interstate travel to facilitate bribery and perjury with respect to receipt of $25,000 to hinder a federal investigation of a Maryland company in 1965
text: In 1971 Dowdy was [convicted](https://www.nytimes.com/1971/12/31/archives/dowdy-convicted-of-taking-a-bribe-representative-from-texas-could.html) of bribery, conspiracy, and perjury related to accepting $25,000 to hinder a federal investigation of a Maryland company in 1965. On Apr. 16, 1975, the House of Representatives [passed H. Res. 46, 360-37 adding clause 10 to the Code of Official Conduct, stating the policy of the House that a member convicted of a serious crime voluntarily refrain from voting](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/94-1975/h82).

name: Brasco
allegation: bribery to get a Post Office contract for a Mafia-controlled truck company
text: Brasco faced an allegation of bribery to get a Post Office contract for a Mafia-controlled truck company. On Jul. 19, 1974, he was [convicted and did not run for re-election](http://www.nytimes.com/1974/07/20/archives/rep-brasco-guilty-of-bribery-conspiracy-brasco-convicted-of-bribery.html).

name: Podell
allegation: bribery
text: Podell faced an allegation of bribery. In 1974, he was [defeated in the election after indictment](http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=P000399). On Oct. 1, 1974, he [pleaded guilty to conspiracy and conflict of interest](http://www.nytimes.com/1974/10/02/archives/podell-enters-guilty-plea-ending-conspiracy-trial-brooklyn.html).

name: Gallagher
allegation: tax evasion and perjury
text: Gallagher faced an allegation of tax evasion and perjury. In 1972, he was [defeated in the primary](http://www.nytimes.com/1973/06/16/archives/gallagher-gets-2-years-and-10000-fine-gallagher-gets-2year-sentence.html). On Jun. 15, 1973, he [pleaded guilty and was sentenced to two years in prison and a $10,000 fine](http://www.nytimes.com/1973/06/16/archives/gallagher-gets-2-years-and-10000-fine-gallagher-gets-2year-sentence.html).

name: Whalley
allegation: taking kickbacks from congressional employees for personal use
text: Whalley faced an allegation of taking kickbacks from congressional employees for personal use. In 1973, he [resigned from Congress and pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice and mail fraud](https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1980/03/12/john-irving-whalley-77-ex-gop-representative/f0499117-f35e-480f-8546-a305203a3b15/?utm_term=.6859dca0c422).

name: Kennedy
allegation: on July 18, 1969, leaving the scene of an accident after driving a car into the Poucha Pond inlet while his passenger Mary Jo Kopechne drowned
text: On July 18, 1969, Kennedy faced an allegation of leaving the scene of an accident after driving a car into the Poucha Pond inlet while his passenger Mary Jo Kopechne drowned. On Jul. 25, 1969, he [pleaded guilty and received a suspended sentence](http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9506E5DD133CE73BBC4E51DFB1668382679EDE&legacy=true).

name: Powell
allegation: using committee travel funds for personal travel while Chairman of Education and Labor committee, improperly authorizing clerk hire payments to his wife and contempt of court (failed to comply with four state court orders, including one criminal conviction for contempt)
text: Powell faced an allegation of using committee travel funds for personal travel while Chairman of Education and Labor committee, other misuse of funds, and contempt of court. He was [excluded, 307-116](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/90-1967/h15) on Mar. 1, 1967, then [reelected in a special election but did not take the seat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam_Clayton_Powell_Jr.#Political_controversy), and on Jan. 3, 1969, he was [seated to the 91st Cong. and fined $25,000, 254-158](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adam_Clayton_Powell_Jr.#Political_controversy). In 1969, the [Supreme Court held the exclusion unconstitutional, see (Powell v. McCormack, 395 U.S. 486](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: McKneally
allegation: tax evasion revealed during the last month of the 1970 election
text: McKneally faced an allegation of tax evasion revealed during the last month of the 1970 election. In 1970, he was [defeated](http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000530). On Oct. 19, 1971, he [pleaded guilty to one count of failing to report income for tax purposes for the years 1964-1967](http://www.nytimes.com/1971/10/19/archives/exrepresentative-says-he-is-guilty-of-tax-evasion.html).

name: Brewster
allegation: in 1969, after he lost his re-election campaign for the Senate, Brewster was indicted for bribery while a U.S. Senator
text: In 1969, after he lost his re-election campaign for the Senate, Brewster was indicted for bribery while a U.S. Senator. In 1975, he [pleaded no contest to a single charge of accepting an illegal gratuity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_Brewster#Bribery_charges).

name: Dodd
allegation: personal use of campaign funds and unbecoming conduct in a senator
text: Dodd faced an allegation of personal use of campaign funds and unbecoming conduct in a senator. On Feb. 23, 1966, he made a [request for committee investigation](https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/common/censure_cases/135ThomasDodd.htm). On Apr. 27, 1967, the Senate Select Committee on Standards and Conduct [recommended censure](https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/common/censure_cases/pdf/135DoddApril27_1967report.pdf). On Jun. 23, 1967, the Senate [censured him, 92-5](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/90-1967/s112). In 1970, he [was not re-elected](https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/common/censure_cases/pdf/135DoddApril27_1967report.pdf).

name: Boykin
allegation: conspiracy and conflict of interest
text: Boykin was found guilty of conspiracy and conflict of interest. In 1962, after reapportionment reduced Alabama's Congressional delegation by one seat in 1962, Alabama held a single statewide election for its representatives with all of the current representatives running against each other. [Boykin placed last](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_W._Boykin#Career) and therefore was not re-elected. In 1963, he was [convicted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_W._Boykin#Conviction). In 1964, he was [pardoned by President Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_W._Boykin#Conviction).

name: Johnson
allegation: accepting an illegal gratuity
text: Johnson faced an allegation of accepting an illegal gratuity. In 1962, he was [defeated in the election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Francis_Johnson). In 1968, he was [convicted of conspiracy and conflict of interest](http://www.nytimes.com/1988/02/03/obituaries/thomas-johnson-78-lost-post-in-congress.html).

name: Lane
allegation: tax evasion
text: Lane faced an allegation of tax evasion. In 1956, he was [convicted and served four months in prison while still in Congress and was re-elected subsequently](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_J._Lane#Congress).

name: Bramblett
allegation: engaging in payroll fraud
text: Bramblett faced an allegation of engaging in payroll fraud. In 1954, he was [convicted and not a candidate for re-election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernest_K._Bramblett).

name: McCarthy
allegation: abuse of a Senate committee
text: McCarthy abused a Senate committee. On Dec. 2, 1954, the Senate [censured him, 67-22](https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/resources/pdf/1954McCarthyCensure.pdf).

name: McCarthy
allegation: corruption
text: McCarthy faced an allegation of corruption. On Jan. 2, 1953, the Senate Subcommittee on Privileges and Elections issued a report with no specific recommendations for Senate action and thus the Senate took no action even though the Subcommittee [did find evidence of improper behavior by McCarthy](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=431). In 1953, the Department of Justice announced it had found no evidence of wrongdoing and [closed the case](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=431).

name: Brehm
allegation: illegal campaign contributions
text: Brehm faced an allegation of illegal campaign contributions. On Apr. 30, 1951, he was [convicted and fined $5,000](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_E._Brehm#Conviction). In 1952, he was [not a candidate for re-election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walter_E._Brehm#Conviction).

name: Thomas
allegation: payroll fraud
text: Thomas faced an allegation of payroll fraud. On Nov. 30, 1949, he [pleaded no contest and served nine months in prison](http://www.nytimes.com/1970/11/20/archives/jparnell-thomas-antired-crusader-is-dead-headed-house-committee-on.html). On Jan. 2, 1950, he [resigned](http://www.nytimes.com/1970/11/20/archives/jparnell-thomas-antired-crusader-is-dead-headed-house-committee-on.html).

name: May
allegation: war profiteering by accepting bribes to use his official position to secure munitions contracts during World War Two
text: May faced an allegation of war profiteering by accepting bribes to use his official position to secure munitions contracts during World War Two. In 1946, he was [defeated in the election](http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000272). On Jul. 3, 1947, he was [convicted](http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000272). In 1950, he [served nine months in prison](http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000272). In 1952, he was [pardoned by President Truman](http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000272).

name: Bilbo
allegation: campaign irregularities, voter intimidation against African-American voters and corruption
text: Bilbo faced allegations of campaign irregularities, voter intimidation against African-American voters and corruption. In 1946, the Senate established a special committee to investigate election practices in the 1946 MS senate election and separately had the [Special Committee to Investigate the National Defense Program also investigate Bilbo](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=410). On Aug. 21, 1947, while fellow white supremacist senators from Southern states filibustered an attempt to expel Bilbo, the discussion was tabled so Bilbo could receive treatment for cancer of the mouth. [He died on August 21, 1947 and no formal action was ever taken](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=413).

name: Langer
allegation: bribery, receiving kickbacks, collecting fees for fictitious services and converting proceeds from litigation settlements
text: Langer faced an allegation of bribery, receiving kickbacks, collecting fees for fictitious services and converting proceeds from litigation settlements. On Jan. 29, 1942, the Committee on Privileges and Elections recommended that Langer was not entitled to his seat due to a lack of moral fitness to be a senator and [recommended he be excluded by a majority vote](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=403). On Mar. 27, 1942, the Senate [vote on exclusion but failed 30-52](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/77-1942/s120).

name: Hoeppel
allegation: selling military appointments
text: Hoeppel faced an allegation of selling military appointments. In 1936, he was [convicted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_H._Hoeppel#Political_career). In 1936, he was an [unsuccessful candidate for election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_H._Hoeppel#Political_career).

name: Long
allegation: using Louisiana state employees and resources for the U.S. Senate campaign of John Overton versus Edwin Broussard, coercing campaign contributions from and for the same and promising immediate release to prisoners in exchange for supporting Overton at the polls and thus so corrupted the election that the results should be invalidated
text: Long faced allegations of previously using Louisiana state employees and resources for the campaign of Sen. John Overton and promising release to prisoners in exchange for supporting Overton at the polls. By Jun. 16, 1934, the investigating committees concluded that no specific action was warranted, partly because many of the contested activities were legal in Louisiana at that time and partly due to a lack of evidence. On Sep. 1, 1935, [Long was assassinated before he could finish his Senate term or complete his campaign to run for president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huey_Long#Assassination_and_aftermath).

name: Rowbottom
allegation: accepting bribes for appointments to the U.S. Post Office
text: Rowbottom faced an allegation of accepting bribes for appointments to the U.S. Post Office. In 1930, he was an [unsuccessful candidate for election](http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=R000474). On Apr. 16, 1931, he was [convicted](http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F05E0DC1F38E03ABC4E52DFB266838A629EDE&legacy=true).

name: Bingham
allegation: hiring a lobbyist who was still being paid by a manufacturing organization
text: Bingham hired a lobbyist who was still being paid by a manufacturing organization. On Nov. 4, 1929, the Senate [censured him 54-22](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=371).

name: Smith
allegation: corrupt campaign practices in both the primary and general election to the Senate that should preclude him from being seated
text: On May. 19, 1926, Smith's admitted excessive campaign contributions from a utility company he regulated. Smith won election anyway in 1926, but was appointed before being seated to a vacant Senate seat. The Senate refused to seat Smith.

name: Gould
allegation: bribery more than a decade before his time in office
text: Gould faced an allegation of bribery more than a decade before his time in office, and the Senate considered whether to prevent him from taking his seat. On Mar. 4, 1927, the Committee on Privileges and Elections recommended the Senate dismiss all charges in part because 14 year old charges did not and should not affect the legality of his election.

name: Bratton
allegation: election irregularities that changed the outcome of the election
text: Bratton faced an allegation of election irregularities that changed the outcome of the election. On Apr. 30, 1926, the Committee on Privileges and Elections unanimously found that the accuser had failed to prove corruption or a change in the election outcome and recommended no further action. On Apr. 30, 1926, the Senate [adopted the committee report](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=352).

name: Schall
allegation: campaign misconduct
text: Schall faced an allegation of campaign misconduct. On Jun. 26, 1926, the Committee on Privileges and Elections recommended unanimously that Schall retain his seat. On Jun. 16, 1926, the Senate [adopted the committee recommendation](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=350).

name: Langley
allegation: violating the National Prohibition Act
text: Langley faced an allegation of violating the National Prohibition Act and in 1924 was convicted. On May. 15, 1924, a special committee deferred action until conclusion of criminal case and appeals. In 1925, he was re-elected. On Nov. 13, 1925, the conviction was affirmed by appeals court. On Dec. 22, 1925, the special committee concluded that House could not expel a member for action prior to election and recommended no action until decision by Supreme Court. In Jan. 1926, the Supreme Court declined to review the case. On Jan. 11, 1926, he [resigned](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Zihlman
allegation: “certain sums of money were paid to two members of Congress” according to a grand jury report to court in 1924
text: Zihlman faced an allegation that “certain sums of money were paid to two members of Congress” according to a grand jury report to court in 1924. On May. 15, 1924, a [special committee recommended no further action against Zihlman](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Wheeler
allegation: representing clients in cases in which the U.S. was an interested party (indicted in Montana)
text: Wheeler faced an allegation of representing clients in cases in which the U.S. was an interested party (indicted in Montana). On Apr. 9, 1924, Wheeler requested a special committee to investigate the indictment because he contended it was retaliation for his investigations into the Justice Department's failure to prosecute government officials implicated in the Teapot Dome scandal. On May. 14, 1924, the special committee exonerated Wheeler. On May. 23, 1924, the Senate voted to agree with the committee report 56-5. In 1925, [wheeler was acquitted in the Montana case](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=343).

name: Newberry
allegation: election fraud
text: Newberry faced an allegation of election fraud. On Mar. 20, 1920, the Senate convicted him of bribery. On May. 2, 1921, the Supreme Court overturned the Senate conviction. On Jan. 12, 1922, the Senate affirmed his election 46-41. On Nov. 18, 1922, he [resigned](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=336).

name: Blanton
allegation: inserting a document in Congressional Record containing indecent and obscene language on October 22, 1921
text: Blanton faced an allegation of inserting a document in Congressional Record containing indecent and obscene language on October 22, 1921. On Oct. 27, 1921, he was [censured (“resolution of reprimand and censure”), 293-0](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/67-1/h120). On Oct. 28, 1921, [apologized](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: La Follette
allegation: disloyalty to the United States by speaking against U.S. participation in World War I
text: La Follette faced an allegation of disloyalty to the United States by speaking against U.S. participation in World War I. On Jan. 16, 1919, the Committee on Privileges and Elections majority report recommended dismissing charges. On Jan. 16, 1919, the Senate [voted 50-21 to dismiss the charges](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=333).

name: Newberry
allegation: corrupt election spending
text: Newberry faced an allegation of corrupt election spending. On Mar. 20, 1920, he was found guilty of campaign finance violations. On May. 2, 1921, the Supreme Court struck down the conviction. On Sep. 29, 1921, the Committee on Privileges and Elections exonerated Newberry in the majority report. On Jan. 12, 1922, the Senate [condemned Newberry for excessive expenditures, but did not unseat him](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/67-2/s206).

name: Sutherland
allegation: illegal campaign activities
