text: Sutherland faced an allegation of illegal campaign activities. On Jun. 26, 1918, the Committee on Privileges and Elections recommended Sutherland retain his seat due to a lack of evidence. On Jun. 28, 1918, the Senate [adopted the committee's recommendation](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=331).

name: McDermott
allegation: bribery by National Association of Manufacturers and other groups in June 1913, alleged by newspapers
text: McDermott faced an allegation of bribery by National Association of Manufacturers and other groups in June 1913, alleged by newspapers. On Dec. 9, 1913, the Select Committee to Investigate Lobby Charges recommended censure of McDermott and exonerated six other members. On Apr. 24, 1914, the House Committee on the Judiciary recommended a resolution “strongly” condemning the conduct of McDermott. On Jul. 21, 1914, he resigned. On Nov. 3, 1914, he was [re-elected](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Watson
allegation: bribery to secure a Senate seat
text: Watson faced an allegation of bribery to secure a Senate seat. On Feb. 11, 1913, the Committee on Privileges and Elections unanimously recommended no further action. On Feb. 11, 1913, the Senate [adopted the recommendation](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=322).

name: Chilton
allegation: bribery to secure a Senate seat
text: Chilton faced an allegation of bribery to secure a Senate seat. On Feb. 11, 1913, the Committee on Privileges and Elections unanimously recommended no further action. On Feb. 11, 1913, the Senate [adopted the recommendation](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=322).

name: Stephenson
allegation: electoral misconduct, bribery, and corruption
text: Stephenson faced an allegation of electoral misconduct, bribery, and corruption. On Jun. 11, 1911, the Committee on Privileges and Elections issued a majority report recommending he retain his seat and the minority report disagreeing. On Mar. 12, 1912, the Senate [voted to allow him to keep his seate 40-34](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=319).

name: Lorimer
allegation: electoral misconduct, bribery, and corruption of a state legislature in order to secure election to the Senate
text: Lorimer committed electoral misconduct, bribery, and corruption of a state legislature in order to secure election to the Senate (this was immediately before the 17th Amendement passed providing for direct election of senators). On Mar. 1, 1911, the Senate vote to unseat him failed 40-46. But on Jul. 13, 1912, the Senate unseated him by a vote of 55-28.

name: Cassel
allegation: fraud related to the construction of the Pennsylvania State Capitol
text: Cassel faced an allegation of fraud related to the construction of the Pennsylvania State Capitol. In 1909, he was [convicted and was not re-elected](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_B._Cassel).

name: Lilley
allegation: contempt of House for making false charges of corruption regarding another member
text: Lilley faced an allegation of contempt of House for making false charges of corruption regarding another member. On May. 20, 1908, the [Select Committee concluded Lilley made false allegations against another member and acted in contempt of House](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf). On May. 20, 1908, the House of Representatives [approved the report and conclusions of Select committee, 159- 82](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/60-1/h191).

name: Smoot
allegation: Mormonism
text: Smoot faced an allegation of Mormonism, which was indeed his religion. On Jun. 2, 1906, the Committee on Privileges and Elections recommended expulsion 7-5 solely because he was a Mormon. On Feb. 20, 1907, the Senate [first decided to require a 2/3 majority for expulsion which failed 27-43, and second to unseat him, which also failed 28-42](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=306).

name: Mitchell
allegation: using political influence in the federal government to help clients with land claims
text: Mitchell faced an allegation of using political influence in the federal government to help clients with land claims. In 1905, his [indictment and conviction occured during Senate recess](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=33). On Dec. 8, 1905, he [died](http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=M000818).

name: Dietrich
allegation: improprieties in postal appointments while Nebraska governor
text: Dietrich faced an allegation of improprieties in postal appointments while Nebraska governor. On Feb. 1, 1904, Dietrich requested an investigation into charges he had accepted bribes for postal appointments even though the charges were dismissed in January 1904. On Apr. 14, 1904, [the special committee unanimously exonerated Dietrich and no further action was taken](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=310).

name: Burton
allegation: accepting compensation for services before a federal agency
text: Burton was convicted of accepting compensation for services before a federal agency. On May. 21, 1906, his final conviction was upheld after the first had been overturned and he'd been convicted again. From 1904 to this point, Burton had not voted in the Senate to avoid triggering an explusion vote. On May 22, 1906, the issue was referred to the Committee on Privileges and Elections. On Jun. 4, 1906, he [resigned](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=309).

name: McLaurin
allegation: an altercation on February 22, 1902 in which Sen. Tillman accused Sen. McLaurin of treachery while McLaurin was off the Senate floor for a committee meeting. Upon hearing about the remarks, McLaurin rushed to the Senate floor and accused Tillman of lying. Tillman then attacked McLaurin physically and efforts to separate them resulted in collateral punching injuries to other senators on the floor
text: McLaurin had an altercation on February 22, 1902 in which Sen. Tillman accused Sen. McLaurin of treachery, then McLaurin accused Tillman of lying. Tillman then attacked McLaurin physically. After a fight almost broke out again, the Senate [censured them both 54-12](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=303).

name: Tillman
allegation: an altercation on February 22, 1902 in which Sen. Tillman accused Sen. McLaurin of treachery while McLaurin was off the Senate floor for a committee meeting. Upon hearing about the remarks, McLaurin rushed to the Senate floor and accused Tillman of lying. Tillman then attacked McLaurin physically and efforts to separate them resulted in collateral punching injuries to other senators on the floor
text: Tillman had an altercation on February 22, 1902 in which he accused Sen. McLaurin of treachery, then McLaurin accused Tillman of lying. Tillman then attacked McLaurin physically. After a fight almost broke out again, the Senate [censured them both 54-12](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=303).

name: Clark
allegation: bribery to win a Senate seat
text: Clark faced an allegation of bribery to win a Senate seat. On Apr. 23, 1900, the Committee on Privileges and Elections unanimously concluded he was not entitled to his seat and [recommended a vote to unseat him](https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/common/contested_elections/pdf/89_Apr_23_1900_Clark.pdf). On May. 15, 1900, he resigned rather than be voted out. In 1901, he was elected to fill the vacancy he'd just created by a Montana legislature filled with winning candidates he'd financially supported.

name: Hanna
allegation: bribery to win a Senate seat
text: Hanna faced an allegation of bribery to win a Senate seat. On Feb. 28, 1899, the Committee on Privileges and Elections [majority report found in favor of Hanna](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=290).

name: Roach
allegation: embezzlement
text: Roach faced an allegation of embezzlement. In 1893, he [was not expelled because the embezzlement had occured 13 years earlier](https://www.senate.gov/artandhistory/history/common/briefing/Expulsion_Censure.htm).

name: Bynum
allegation: insulting another member during debate on May 17, 1890
text: Bynum faced an allegation of insulting another member during debate on May 17, 1890. On May. 17, 1890, he was [censured 126-104](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/51-1/h174).

name: Turpie
allegation: misconduct by the Indiana Senate to secure Turpie's election
text: Turpie faced an allegation of misconduct by the Indiana Senate to secure Turpie's election. On Mar. 4, 1888, the Committee on Privileges and Elections recommended no action since even if the charges were true the U.S. Senate had no jurisdiction over the Indiana Senate. On May. 15, 1888, the Senate [voted by voice to discharge the committee from further investigation](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=262).

name: Payne
allegation: bribery and corruption in the election
text: Payne faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in the election. On Jul. 15, 1886, the Committee on Privileges and Elections submitted multiple reports with no conclusive recommendations. On Jul. 23, 1886, the Senate [voted to discharge the committee from further investigation](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=259).

name: Kellogg
allegation: corruption for conduct that occurred prior to election to the House
text: Kellogg faced an allegation of corruption for conduct that occurred prior to election to the House. On May. 23, 1884, [Kellogg asked the Department of Justice  to investigate and the resolution was referred to the Judiciary committee, 82-49; but no report appears to have been made](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Voorhis
allegation: insulting another member during debate on March 1, 1883
text: Voorhis faced an allegation of insulting another member during debate on March 1, 1883. Voorhis apologized prior to a censure vote and on Mar. 1, 1883, the House of Representatives [failed to censure him, 66-78](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Lapham
allegation: election corruption
text: Lapham faced an allegation of election corruption. On Dec. 3, 1881, the Committee on Privileges and Elections recommended in an oral report that no further action for lack of evidence of wrongdoing. On Dec. 13, 1881, the Senate [discharged the committee from further action](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=255).

name: Miller
allegation: election corruption
text: Miller faced an allegation of election corruption. On Dec. 3, 1881, the Committee on Privileges and Elections recommended in an oral report that no further action for lack of evidence of wrongdoing. On Dec. 13, 1881, the Senate [discharged the committee from further action](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=255).

name: Ingalls
allegation: bribery and corruption in the election
text: Ingalls faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in the election. On Feb. 17, 1880, the Committee on Privileges and Elections concluded that while bribery and corruption were present, there was no evidence tying them to Ingalls or that it had altered election results and therefore the charges should be dismissed.

name: Matthews
allegation: corruption before serving in the Senate
text: Matthews faced an allegation of corruption before serving in the Senate. On Mar. 1, 1879, a [Select Committee unanimously found Matthews had not committed fraud, but had given the appearance of impropriety](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=247).

name: Grover
allegation: bribery and corruption in the election
text: Grover faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in the election. On Jun. 15, 1878, the Committee on Privileges and Elections [dismissed the charges](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=245).

name: Smalls
allegation: accepting a bribe while a state legislator in 1872
text: Smalls faced an allegation of accepting a bribe while a state legislator in 1872. On Nov. 11, 1877, he was convicted and was sentenced to three years imprisonment, for which he served three days. On Dec. 3, 1877, he was released on bail pending appeal. On Jan. 25, 1878, the House Committee on the Judiciary investigated the circumstances of the conviction and determined that arrest by state authorities for an alleged state crime and detention for trial did not violate any right or privilege of the House. On Apr. 23, 1879, he was [pardoned by governor](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Blaine
allegation: selling worthless bonds to Union Pacific Railroad for $64,000
text: Blaine faced an allegation of selling worthless bonds to Union Pacific Railroad for $64,000. On Jun. 6, 1876, the House Committee on the Judiciary ordered a report. On Jul. 10, 1876, he [resigned](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Hays
allegation: accepting money to nominate an individual not from his district to military academy and making false certification regarding residency of the nominee
text: Hays faced an allegation of accepting money to nominate an individual not from his district to military academy and making false certification regarding residency of the nominee. On Jul. 19, 1876, the committee recommended 4-2 that the House take no further action but concluded Hays' actions “excites grave suspicions, and shows in any possible view a carelessness which ought not to be tolerated”. On Aug. 6, 1876, the [report of the Judiciary Committee was tabled](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: King
allegation: corruption and false testimony before congressional committee
text: King faced an allegation of corruption and false testimony before congressional committee. On Aug. 9, 1876, the [majority report of the Judiciary committee concluded 16-7 that the House had no jurisdiction to investigate an alleged offense committed in a previous Congress that was being reviewed by the courts](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Schumaker
allegation: corruption and false testimony before congressional committee
text: Schumaker faced an allegation of corruption and false testimony before congressional committee. On Aug. 9, 1876, the [majority report of the Judiciary committee concluded 16-7 that the House had no jurisdiction to investigate an alleged offense committed in a previous Congress that was being reviewed by the courts](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Brown
allegation: insulting a member in debate and lying to the Speaker on February 4, 1875
text: Brown faced an allegation of insulting a member in debate and lying to the Speaker on February 4, 1875. On Feb. 4, 1875, the House of Representatives [censured him, 161-79](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/votes/43-2/h377). On May. 2, 1876, the House of Representatives unanimously agreed to resolution rescinding portion of censure regarding comments to Speaker because [the former Speaker concluded Brown “did not in any way intend to prevaricate or deceive the House”](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Bogy
allegation: bribery and corruption in the election
text: Bogy faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in the election. On Mar. 25, 1873, the Committee on Privileges and Elections recommended no further action and the Senate [voted to adopt committee report](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=230).

name: Allison
allegation: bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America
text: Allison faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America. On Feb. 27, 1873, the Morrill Committee made no recommendation.

name: Bayard
allegation: bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America
text: Bayard faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America. On Feb. 27, 1873, the Morrill Committee made no recommendation.

name: Boutwell
allegation: bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America
text: Boutwell faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America. On Feb. 27, 1873, the Morrill Committee made no recommendation.

name: Colfax
allegation: bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America
text: Colfax faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America. On Feb. 27, 1873, the Morrill Committee made no recommendation. On Feb. 20, 1873, the House of Representatives impeachment resolution was introduced. On Mar. 4, 1873, his [term as Vice President and President of the Senate ended](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=223).

name: Harlan
allegation: bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America
text: Harlan faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America. On Feb. 27, 1873, the Morrill Committee recommended censure. On Mar. 4, 1873, his term ended.

name: Logan
allegation: bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America
text: Logan faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America. On Feb. 27, 1873, the Morrill Committee dismissed the charges.

name: Conkling
allegation: bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America
text: Conkling faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America. On Feb. 27, 1873, the Morrill Committee dismissed the charges.

name: Wilson
allegation: bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America
text: Wilson faced an allegation of bribery and corruption in management of Union Pacific Railroad and Credit Mobilier of America. On Feb. 27, 1873, the Morrill Committee no formal recommendation, but he was reprimanded in report.

name: Patterson
allegation: corruption in Credit Mobilier stock share purchases
text: Patterson faced an allegation of corruption in Credit Mobilier stock share purchases. On Feb. 27, 1873, the Morrill Committee made an unanimous recommendation of expulsion. In 1873, the Senate [took no action due to expiration of Patterson's term](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=223).

name: Pomeroy
allegation: bribery to secure votes for a Senate seat
text: Pomeroy faced an allegation of bribery to secure votes for a Senate seat. On Jun. 3, 1872, the Committee on Privileges and Elections dismissed the charges. On Mar. 3, 1873, having lost re-election, Pomeroy requested another investigation and the special committee investigating issued majority and minority reports. However, because the report came on the last day of his term, [no further action was taken](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=208).

name: Caldwell
allegation: bribery to secure votes for a Senate seat
text: Caldwell faced an allegation of bribery to secure votes for a Senate seat. On Feb. 17, 1873, the committee reported unanimously that Caldwell had bribed legislators for their votes and recommended a declaration of a voided election. On Mar. 24, 1873, he [resigned before a Senate vote](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=208).

name: Clayton
allegation: corruption while governor of Arkansas
text: Clayton faced an allegation of corruption while governor of Arkansas. On Feb. 26, 1873, the charges were dismissed. On Mar. 25, 1873, the Senate [accepted the committee report 33-6](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=204).

name: Brooks
allegation: soliciting and accepting 50 shares of Credit Mobilier stock at undervalued price
text: Brooks faced an allegation of soliciting and accepting 50 shares of Credit Mobilier stock at undervalued price. On Feb. 13, 1873, a special committee recommended expulsion. On Feb. 27, 1873, the House of Representatives [censured him, 174-32](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj07364))).

name: Ames
allegation: selling $33 million in Credit Mobilier stock to members of Congress and officials of the executive branch at undervalued price with intent to influence votes and decisions of the members
text: Ames faced an allegation of selling $33 million in Credit Mobilier stock to members of Congress and officials of the executive branch at undervalued price with intent to influence votes and decisions of the members. On Feb. 18, 1873, a special committee recommended expulsion but the Judiciary committee recommended against expulsion because the acts in question occurred three years before his election to the 42nd Congress. On Feb. 27, 1873, the House of Representatives [censured him, 182- 36](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj07364))).

name: Butler
allegation: accepting money for recommending appointment to military academy
text: Butler faced an allegation of accepting money for recommending appointment to military academy. On Mar. 16, 1870, the Committee on Military Affairs recommended censure. On Mar. 16, 1870, the House of Representatives [censured him, 150-0](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj06970))).

name: Deweese
allegation: accepting money for recommending appointment to military academy
text: Deweese faced an allegation of accepting money for recommending appointment to military academy. On Feb. 28, 1870, he [resigned](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf). On Mar. 1, 1870, the Committee on Military Affairs recommended censure and the House of Representatives [censured him, 170-0](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj06957))).

name: Revels
allegation: officially, not holding citizenship for the required nine years at the time of presenting his credentials to the Senate on February 23, 1870 in order to become the first black American to serve there. However, based on the racist arguments offered during debate on the issue, the allegation was actually that he was black
text: Revels faced an allegation of, officially, not holding citizenship for the required nine years at the time of presenting his credentials to the Senate on February 23, 1870 in order to become the first black American to serve there. However, based on the racist arguments offered during debate on the issue, the allegation was actually that he was black. On Feb. 25, 1870, the [Senate voted to accept his credentials 48-8](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=187).

name: Whittemore
allegation: selling appointments to military academies
text: Whittemore faced an allegation of selling appointments to military academies. On Feb. 21, 1870, the Committee on Military Affairs recommended expulsion. On Feb. 24, 1870, the House of Representatives [censured him, 187-0](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj06954))). On Jun. 21, 1870, he resigned prior to censure, but then was reelected to the same session of the House and then excluded from the House again, [130-76](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Holbrook
allegation: accusing another member of lying during debate on February 4, 1869
text: Holbrook faced an allegation of accusing another member of lying during debate on February 4, 1869. On Feb. 4, 1869, he was [censured by the Speaker with no recorded vote](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj06737))).

name: Wood
allegation: describing Reconstruction legislation as a “monstrosity” on January 15, 1868
text: Wood faced an allegation of describing Reconstruction legislation as a “monstrosity” on January 15, 1868 and that day the House of Representatives [censured him, 114-39](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj06627))).

name: Hunter
allegation: accusing another member of lying during debate on January 26, 1867
text: Hunter faced an allegation of accusing another member of lying during debate on January 26, 1867 and on that day the House of Representatives [censured him, 77-33](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj06436))).

name: Rousseau
allegation: assaulting Rep. Grinnell with a cane outside the Capitol for an alleged insult spoken in debate
text: Rep. Rousseau faced an allegation of assaulting Rep. Grinnell with a cane outside the Capitol for an alleged insult spoken in debate. On Jul. 2, 1866, a special committee recommended expulsion. On Jul. 17, 1866, the House of Representatives [censured him, 89-30](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj063168))). On Jul. 21, 1866, he resigned. On Dec. 3, 1866, he was [re-elected to fill the vacancy his own resignation created](http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=R000468).

name: Chanler
allegation: “[A]ttempted a gross insult to the House” by proposing a resolution supporting vetoes issued by President Johnson on May 14, 1864
text: Chanler faced an allegation of “[A]ttempted a gross insult to the House” by proposing a resolution supporting vetoes issued by President Johnson on May 14, 1864 and on the same day the House of Representatives [censured him, 72-30](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj063116))).

name: Long
allegation: supporting recognition of the independence of the Confederacy in speech on floor of the House on April 8, 1864
text: Long faced an allegation of supporting recognition of the independence of the Confederacy in speech on floor of the House on April 8, 1864 and on the same day the House of Representatives [censured him, 80- 70](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj06190))).

name: Harris
allegation: encouraging the Confederacy on April 9, 1864 during House debate on resolution to expel Long
text: Harris faced an allegation of encouraging the Confederacy on April 9, 1864 during House debate on resolution to expel Long. On Apr. 14, 1864, the House of Representatives [censured him, 98-20](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj06187))).

name: Burnett
allegation: open rebellion against the government of the United States
text: Burnett faced an allegation of open rebellion against the government of the United States. On Dec. 3, 1861, the House of Representatives [expelled him, but no vote recorded](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj0594))).

name: Reid
allegation: taking up arms against the government of the United States
text: Reid faced an allegation of taking up arms against the government of the United States. On Dec. 2, 1861, the House of Representatives [expelled him, but no vote recorded)](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj0593))).

name: Clark
allegation: taking up arms against the government of the United States
text: Clark faced an allegation of taking up arms against the government of the United States. On Jul. 13, 1861, the House of Representatives [expelled him, 94-45](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05811))).

name: Simmons
allegation: corruption
text: Simmons faced an allegation of corruption. On Jul. 14, 1862, the Senate Committee on the Judiciary recommended that Senate take such action as it deemed appropriate, but also that the charges were all true. On Aug. 15, 1862, he [resigned](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=149).

name: Stark
allegation: disloyalty to the Union
text: Stark faced an allegation of disloyalty to the Union. On Feb. 27, 1862, the Senate voted to seat him 26-19 since his public statements came before he was in the Senate. On Feb. 28, 1862, Stark requested another investigation, presumably to more fully exonerate him. On Apr. 22, 1862, the committee reported that based on Stark's public statements, he supported the rebellion and Charles Sumner introduced a resolution to expel him. On Jun. 6, 1862, the Senate expulsion vote was defeated 21-16, apparently because Stark had only a few more months to serve.

name: Bright
allegation: disloyalty to the Union
text: Bright faced an allegation of disloyalty to the Union. On Jan. 13, 1862, the Senate Committee on the Judiciary recommended against expulsion. On Feb. 5, 1863, the Senate [expelled him, 32-14](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=140).

name: Johnson
allegation: disloyalty to the Union
text: Johnson faced an allegation of disloyalty to the Union. On Jan. 9, 1862, the Senate Committee on the Judiciary recommended expulsion since he had not appeared that session and was rumored to be a Confederate officer. On Jan. 10, 1862, the Senate [expelled him, 35-0](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=138).

name: Polk
allegation: disloyalty to the Union
text: Polk faced an allegation of disloyalty to the Union. name: Matteson

text: Matteson faced an allegation of corruption during a preceding Congress. name: Cameron

text: Cameron faced an allegation of election irregularities and electoral misconduct. On Mar. 9, 1857, Cameron asked for a Judiciary Committee investigation. On Mar. 13, 1857, the Senate Committee on the Judiciary [dismissed the charges](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=114).

name: Edwards
allegation: accepting money for supporting legislation
text: Edwards faced an allegation of accepting money for supporting legislation. On Feb. 19, 1857, a [special committee recommended expulsion in the majority report](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05363))). On Feb. 28, 1857, the House of Representatives [expulsion resolution was tabled after his resignation](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05370))).

name: Matteson
allegation: “defam[ing] character of House” by accepting money in exchange for supporting the Minnesota land bill
text: Matteson faced an allegation of “defam[ing] character of House” by accepting money in exchange for supporting the Minnesota land bill. On Feb. 19, 1857, a [special committee recommended expulsion in the majority report, but the minority report found committee lacked jurisdiction](https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc30796/m1/280/?q=expulsion). On Feb. 27, 1857, the House of Representatives [censured him, 145-17 while the expulsion resolution was tabled](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05370))). On Feb. 27, 1857, he resigned prior to House action; reelected later in 1857.

On Feb. 28, 1857, in the House of Representatives the [expulsion resolution was tabled after his resignation](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05370))).

name: Keitt

text: Keitt faced an allegation of complicity in the assault on Sumner. On Jun. 2, 1856, a [select committee recommended censure in a majority report](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05222))). On Jul. 15, 1856, the House of Representatives [censured him,  106-96](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05255))). On Jul. 16, 1856, he resigned after the vote. On Aug. 6, 1856, he was reelected.

On Jul. 15, 1856, the House of Representatives [censure resolution failed, 60-136](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05255))).

name: Brooks
allegation: assaulting Sen. Sumner on the Senate floor after the Senate had adjourned for the day
text: Brooks faced an allegation of assaulting Sen. Sumner on the Senate floor after the Senate had adjourned for the day. On Jun. 2, 1856, a [select committee recommended expulsion](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05222))). On Jul. 14, 1856, the House of Representatives [failed to expel him, 121-95](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05254))). On Jul. 15, 1856, he [resigned after the expulsion vote](http://history.house.gov/People/Listing/B/BROOKS,-Preston-Smith-(B000885)/). On Aug. 1, 1856, he was [re-elected to fill the vacancy he created](http://history.house.gov/People/Listing/B/BROOKS,-Preston-Smith-(B000885)/).

name: Herbert
allegation: fatally shooting a hotel waiter who refused him after-hours breakfast service for which he was arrested on May 8, 1856 and imprisoned prior to trial
text: Herbert faced an allegation of fatally shooting a hotel waiter who refused him after-hours breakfast service for which he was arrested on May 8, 1856 and imprisoned prior to trial. On May. 15, 1856, the House of Representatives [tabled the resolution to refer the case to Judiciary Committee, 79-70](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj05211))). In Jan. 1856, he was [acquitted](https://ethics.house.gov/sites/ethics.house.gov/files/Historical_Chart_Final_Version%20in%20Word_0.pdf).

name: Benton

text: Benton faced an allegation of breach of comity on April 17, 1850 for threatening Foote. On Jun. 30, 1850, a [committee recommended no further action against Benton or Foote since Foote had no intention of actually shooting and Benton had been threatening but hadn't acted](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=91).

text: Shields faced an allegation of not yet being a United States citizen. On May. 8, 1844, when a select committee reported to the full Senate, Senator Archer submitted a resolution for expulsion. On Aug. 10, 1844, the Senate [adopted a substitute resolution of censure, 38-7](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=81).

name: Giddings
allegation: violating House "gag rule" on slavery discussions by introducing a series of resolutions defending a slave rebellion aboard the Creole, a ship that had sailed from Virginia carrying 135 persons to be sold in New Orleans
text: Giddings faced an allegation of violating House "gag rule" on slavery discussions by introducing a series of resolutions defending a slave rebellion aboard the Creole, a ship that had sailed from Virginia carrying 135 persons to be sold in New Orleans. On Mar. 22, 1842, the House of Representatives [censured him, 125-69](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj03788))). On Mar. 22, 1842, he [resigned](http://history.house.gov/HistoricalHighlight/Detail/36674?ret=True). On May. 5, 1842, he was [re-elected to fill the vacancy caused by his own resignation](http://history.house.gov/HistoricalHighlight/Detail/36674?ret=True).

text: Adams faced an allegation of breaching of privileges of the House by presenting a petition to the House from his constituents regarding dissolution of the Union on January 24, 1842. On Feb. 7, 1842, the House of Representatives [tabled the censure resolution, 106-93](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj03751))).

name: Duncan
allegation: violating privileges of the House by publishing remarks in a newspaper insulting to another member on February 19, 1839
text: Duncan faced an allegation of violating privileges of the House by publishing remarks in a newspaper insulting to another member on February 19, 1839. On Feb. 22, 1839, the House of Representatives [tabled the censure resolution](https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc29275/m1/218/?q=duncan).

name: Ruggles
allegation: corruption in using Senatorial influence to secure positive outcomes for a patent application
text: Ruggles faced an allegation of corruption in using Senatorial influence to secure positive outcomes for a patent application. On Apr. 12, 1838, Ruggles effectively discredited his accuser and the committee reported that the charges should be dismissed. On Apr. 25, 1838, the Senate [agreed with the committtee](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=76).

name: Graves
allegation: breach of the privileges of the House because on February 24, 1838 Graves killed Jonathan Cilley in a duel over words spoken in debate while Wise acted as a second
text: Graves faced an allegation of breach of the privileges of the House because on February 24, 1838 he killed Jonathan Cilley in a duel over words spoken in debate while Wise acted as a second. On Apr. 21, 1838, the Select Committee of Investigation recommended expulsion for Graves and censure for Wise. On May. 10, 1838, the House of Representatives [tabled the expulsion resolution ](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj032126))).

name: Adams
allegation: gross disrespect on February 6, 1837 because Adams violated the House "gag rule" on slavery discussions by requesting to present a petition to the House purported to be from slaves. Adams knew a censure resolution would require debate for a vote and thus would provide a way around the gag rule
text: Adams faced an allegation of gross disrespect on February 6, 1837 because Adams violated the House "gag rule" on slavery discussions by requesting to present a petition to the House purported to be from slaves. Adams knew a censure resolution would require debate for a vote and thus would provide a way around the gag rule. On Feb. 9, 1837, the House of Representatives [withdrew the censure resolution, 21-137](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj029206))).

name: Williams
allegation: insulting the chair of the Committee of the Whole during debate by yelling "I shall not take my seat. You take yours!" and "I call you to order!" on July 2, 1836
text: Williams faced an allegation of insulting the chair of the Committee of the Whole during debate by yelling "I shall not take my seat. You take yours!" and "I call you to order!" on July 2, 1836. On Jul. 4, 1836, the House of Representatives [informally censured him, then later revoked the censure](https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc30905/m1/660/?q=williams).

name: Poindexter
allegation: conspiracy to assassinate President Andrew Jackson
text: Poindexter faced an allegation of conspiracy to assassinate President Andrew Jackson. On Feb. 23, 1835, Poindexter requested an investigation, and if the charges were proved, to be expelled from the Senate. On Mar. 2, 1835, the Senate [voted 41-0 to accept the committee's recommendation to dismiss charges](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=72).

name: Adams
allegation: committing a breach of the rules of the House by refusing to vote on Stanbery censure after having his application to be excused from the vote rejected on July 11, 1832
text: Adams faced an allegation of committing a breach of the rules of the House by refusing to vote on Stanbery censure after having his application to be excused from the vote rejected on July 11, 1832. On Jul. 12, 1832, the House of Representatives [tabled the censure resolution, 89-63](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj025176))).

name: Stanbery
allegation: insulting the Speaker during floor debate on July 9, 1832 by saying the House Speaker was too focused on trying to become Speaker
text: Stanbery faced an allegation of insulting the Speaker during floor debate on July 9, 1832 by saying the House Speaker was too focused on trying to become Speaker. On Jul. 11, 1832, the House of Representatives [censured him, 92- 44](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj025175))).

name: Bateman
allegation: casting the deciding vote for himself in his election, which it was suggested was improper
text: Bateman faced an allegation of casting the deciding vote for himself in his election, which it was suggested was improper. On May. 22, 1828, the Senate committee recommended no further action and the Senate agreed. On Jan. 12, 1829, he [resigned due to ill health and died on the 28th](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=67).

name: Pickering
allegation: reading confidential documents in open Senate session on December 31, 1810 without realizing the injunction of secrecy had not been removed
text: Pickering faced an allegation of reading confidential documents in open Senate session on December 31, 1810 without realizing the injunction of secrecy had not been removed. On Dec. 31, 1810, the Senate introduced a resolution of censure. On Jan. 2, 1811, the Senate censured him, 20-7 In 1811, he [lost the election](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=60).

name: Smith
allegation: involvement in Aaron Burr's plot to lead the western territories in rebellion
text: Smith faced an allegation of involvement in Aaron Burr's plot to lead the western territories in rebellion. On Dec. 31, 1807, a commitee reported that it looked like Smith was involved, but did not recommend any specific action. On Apr. 9, 1808, the Senate expulsion failed, 19-10 (one vote short of the 2/3 majority needed). On Apr. 25, 1808, he [resigned](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=52).

name: Lyon
allegation: violating the Sedition Act on October 9, 1798 by accusing President John Adams of having a taste for excessive pomp, for which he was convicted and fined and served four months in prison while a member of the House
text: Lyon faced an allegation of violating Sedition Act on October 9, 1798 by accusing President John Adams of having a taste for excessive pomp, for which he was convicted and fined and served four months in prison while a member of the House. On Feb. 22, 1799, the House of Representatives [failed to expel him, 49-45](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj003301))). In 1799, he was [re-elected after conviction and while still in jail](http://history.house.gov/Historical-Highlights/1800-1850/The-life-of-Representative-Matthew-Lyon-of-Vermont-and-Kentucky/).

name: Blount
allegation: disloyalty to the United States by attempting to start a war between the Creek, Cherokee, and Spain in order to transfer land to Great Britain
text: Blount committed disloyalty to the United States by attempting to start a war between the Creek, Cherokee, and Spain in order to transfer land to Great Britain. On Jul. 8, 1797, the Senate expelled him, 25-1 and ordered him to appear on July 10 for impeachment, which he promised to do, but did not. On Dec. 17, 1798, the Senate [held an impeachment trial in the Senate and in absentia, but the resolution of impeachment failed](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=47).

name: Griswold

text: Griswold faced an allegation of “disorderly behavior” when, incensed that the House failed to expel Lyon for spitting tobacco juice at him in January and unsatisfied with Lyon's apology, Griswold attacked Lyon on February 15, 1798 with a cane while Lyon defended himself with a pair of fireplace tongs. text: Lyon faced an allegation of spitting tobacco juice at Griswold on January 30, 1798. On Feb. 2, 1798, the Committee on Privileges [recommended expulsion](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj003114))). On Feb. 1, 1798, he sent a [letter of apology](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj003113))). On Feb. 12, 1798, the House of Representatives [failed to censure him, 44-52 and failed to expel him, 52-44](https://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/hlaw:@field(DOCID+@lit(hj003120))).

name: Marshall
allegation: misconduct prior to serving in the Senate
text: Marshall faced an allegation of misconduct prior to serving in the Senate. On Mar. 11, 1796, having requested the investigation in order to clear his name of the informal charges of perjury, the committee reported that since there were no charges, there was nothing to investigate and the Senate should take no further action. On Mar. 22, 1796, the Senate [voted 16-7 to investigate no further](https://hdl.handle.net/2027/umn.31951p00933065r?urlappend=%3Bseq=42).
